{{Refimprove|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Bread N' Butter | image = | caption = | creator = [[Progressive Broadcasting Corporation]] and DSR Multimedia Productions Inc. | developer = [[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV 37]] | starring = [[Rodel Flordeliz]]
Kitt Meily
Arlene Razon | country = [[Philippines]] | num_episodes = | executive_producer = Rodel Flordeliz | camera = | runtime = 45 minutes | network = [[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV]] | first_aired = July 23, 2008 | last_aired = July 12, 2016 | followed_by = Serbisyong Kasangbahay }} '''''Bread N' Butter''''' (''lit. Bread and Butter'') is a [[business]] and [[travel]] show produced by DSR Multimedia Productions and airs on UNTV. The program describes itself as a show ''that would inspire [[Filipinos]] to discover their entrepreneurial sense''. The program format is similar to a travel documentary where the main hosts venture and visit various kinds of business establishments.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BocVTvsHebw Bread and Butter (UNTV) - Interviewing] It also features solutions to business problems, which they claim to be helpful to the business-minded audience. It is currently hosted by Arlene Razon, Kitt Meily and [[Rodel Flordeliz]] and airs every Sunday on [[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV]]. The television show uses [[Taglish|Taglish language]] as its means of communication. Bread N' Butter ceased airing on July 12 2016 there replacing Serbisyong Kasangbahay which airing on July 18 There rebranded both programming block on UNTV '''Cancellation''' On July 12 2016 is final episode Of Bread N' Butter to UNTV Life is rebranding UNTV News & Rescue two programming block Public Service which air on july 18 ==Final Past Hosts== * Lynley Teng * Jorell Tabernilla ==Final Hosts== * [[Rodel Flordeliz]] * Kitt Meily * Arlene Razon == References == {{Reflist}} 2. revision.text:
{{short description|South African businessman}} {{third-party|date=March 2013}}
'''Brian Menell''' is a [[South African]] businessman with interests in mining, oil & gas, agriculture & agri industry, and banking.
==Early life and education==
Menell was born in 1965 in [[Johannesburg]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.brianmenellgroup.org/brian-menell/|publisher=Brian Menell Group|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref> His grandfather, Slip Menell, was the co-founder in 1932 of the [[Anglovaal]] Group, one of South Africa's largest diversified mining and industrial groups of companies. His father was the [[philanthropist]] and businessman, Clive Menell, who died in 1996; President [[Nelson Mandela]] gave the address at Clive's memorial service in Johannesburg.<ref>[http://www.anc.org.za/nelson/show.php?id=3332 "Nelson Mandela's Speech at The Memorial Service of Clive Menell"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217225351/http://www.anc.org.za/nelson/show.php?id=3332 |date=December 17, 2013 }}</ref>
Menell was educated at the [[Rugby School]] in the UK. He holds a BA (Hons) from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in [[Political Science]] and [[Economics]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.brianmenellgroup.org/brian-menell/|publisher=Brian Menell Group|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref>
==Career==
===Mining=== Prior to joining Anglovaal Group, Menell worked for the [[De Beers Group]] in London, [[Antwerp]] and [[Windhoek]] for eight years.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shore Gold appoints former Anglovaal, De Beers man Mennell chair|url=http://www.miningweekly.com/article/shore-gold-appoints-former-avmin-de-beers-man-mennell-chair-2012-05-15|website=Mining Weekly|accessdate=14 October 2016}}</ref> He originally joined the company as a diamond sorter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mining Personality- Brian Menell|url=http://www.kemetgroup.net/mining_weekly_04nov_news.php|website=Kemet Group|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref>
Menell was Principal and Executive Director of Anglovaal Mining Ltd. which owned [[precious metal]], [[base metal]], [[ferrous metal]] and diamond interests across [[Southern Africa]]. Menell and his brother Rick retained control of Anglovaal until its sale in 2001 to create the largest [[South African]] empowerment controlled company, [[African Rainbow Minerals]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Brian Menell Group Business|url=http://www.brianmenellgroup.org/business/|website=Brian Menell Group|accessdate=14 October 2016}}</ref> During his time with Anglovaal he was also a 50% partner in the [[Venetia Diamond Mine|Venetia diamond mine]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Shore Gold appoints former Anglovaal, De Beers man Mennell chair|url=http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/shore-gold-appoints-former-avmin-de-beers-man-mennell-chair-2012-05-15/rep_id:4136|website=Mining Weekly|accessdate=14 October 2016}}</ref> De Beers' acquisition of Anglovaal's interest in the mine for $600 million was the largest in the company's history.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shore Gold appoints former Anglovaal, De Beers man Mennell chair|url=http://www.miningweekly.com/print-version/shore-gold-appoints-former-avmin-de-beers-man-mennell-chair-2012-05-15|website=Mining Weekly|accessdate=14 October 2016}}</ref>
In 2017 Brian founded and continues to serve as Chairman and CEO of TechMet Ltd, an investment vehicle for a portfolio of technology metal projects. TechMet acquires and manages projects that produce, process and recycle the key strategic technology metals that go into batteries, electric vehicles and robotics – cobolt, lithium, nickel, tin, tungsten, rare earth metals, vanadium and graphite.
Menell is the Chief Executive Officer of the Kemet Group which invests in and manages mining and other [[natural resource]] projects across the African continent, and advises certain African governments on resource policy and major transactions. He also serves as Chief Executive of Tinco Investments Limited (an integrated [[Tin]] and [[Tungsten]] producer).
Menell is a former Director and Chairman of Shore Gold Inc.,<ref>[http://www.miningweekly.com/article/brian-menell-2011-11-04 MinngWeekly.com "Mining Personality - Brian Menell"]</ref> one of Canada's largest diamond exploration companies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Resource World|url=https://www.pdiam.com/assets/docs/articles/ResourceWorld-May2010.pdf|website=Resource World|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref>
He is also a former Chairman of Energem Resources Inc. and a former Chairman of First Africa Oil Plc.
===Other ventures=== In 2004, Menell became a founding partner and Executive Director of the [[A1 Grand Prix]] auto racing series.<ref>[http://www.southafrica.info/about/sport/features/a1grandprix-sacar.htm South Africa: "A1 Grand Prix: SA Sar Unveiled"]</ref> He is the Chairman of Agricor Ltd (an African [[fertiliser]] and [[feedstock]] company) and is a Director and Chairman of Sallfort Partners AG, a [[private banking]] joint venture headquartered in [[Zurich]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sallfort Partners AG|url=https://www.moneyhouse.ch/en/company/sallfort-partners-ag-14012212991|website=Moneyhouse|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
Through the SG Menell Charitable Fund, Menell invests in disadvantaged communities in both South Africa and the rest of the developing world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brian Menell Charity|url=http://www.brianmenellgroup.org/charity/|website=Brian Menell Group|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== He is married with two children.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mining Personality- Brian Menell|url=http://www.kemetgroup.net/mining_weekly_04nov_news.php|website=Kemet Group|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Menell, Brian}} [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:South African motorsport people]] [[Category:A1 Grand Prix people]] [[Category:Auto racing executives]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Infobox person |name = Carlos Moncayo |birth_date = June 10, 1981 |birth_place = [[Quito, Ecuador]] |image = |caption = |residence = |nationality = Ecuadorian |known_for = |education = MBA |alma_mater = [[Northwestern University]] Kellogg - [[HKUST Business School]] |employer = |occupation = CEO of Asiam Business Group |home_town = |religion = |website = [http://www.asiam.com.cn/ www.asiam.com.cn] }} '''Carlos Moncayo''' (Simplified Chinese 卡罗斯) is an Ecuadorian businessman best known for being co-founder and CEO of Asiam Business Group.
== Early life == Moncayo was born in Quito, Ecuador. He studied law at the Catholic University of Ecuador but took a break from his education to start Asiam Business Group. Despite not completing his undergraduate studies, he was admitted and received his MBA from Kellogg - HKUST Business School, being the first candidate to be admitted in this program without an undergraduate degree. Besides attending Kellogg he has also attended [[Willamette University]], Stanford Graduate School of Business, CEIBS (China Europe International Business School)<ref>[http://www.ceibs.edu/link/latest/51104_4.shtml "ASIAM's Strategic Success"] ''The Link''. Retrieved 2015-2-22.</ref> and Yale University.
== Career == In 2003, Moncayo co-founded, with his two brothers Luis Moncayo and Fernando Moncayo, Asiam Business Group, a boutique offshore manufacturing management company headquartered in China with sourcing offices in Vietnam, India and Pakistan. Moncayo now serves as CEO of Asiam Business Group.<ref>[http://www.thomaswhite.com/global-perspectives/carlos-moncayo-ceo-asiam/ "Emerging Leaders] Thomas White International. Retrieved 2015-2-22.</ref> He is also co-founder and director of Startups Ventures, an organization that supports the education, networking and finance of entrepreneurs in Ecuador. In 2015, Carlos along with his brothers founded the SaaS company [[Inspectorio]]. He serves as the CEO of the company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/minneapolis-startup-inspectorio-raises-10-million-with-help-from-target-ecolab/488045821/|title=Minneapolis startup Inspectorio raises $10 million with help from Target, Ecolab|work=Star Tribune|access-date=2018-07-19}}</ref>
He has been featured or quoted in media outlets including ''Financial Times''<ref>[http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/ce43d9b4-226a-11e0-b6a2-00144feab49a,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2Fce43d9b4-226a-11e0-b6a2-00144feab49a.html%3Fsiteedition%3Dintl&siteedition=intl&_i_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fsearch.ft.com%2Fsearch%3FqueryText%3DMoncayo#axzz3SD6m0Bu4 "Business Dairy: Carlos Moncayo"] ''Financial Times''. Retrieved 2015-2-22.</ref> and ''BBC News''.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/business-19332584 "Ideas Exchange opens for talks"] ''BBC News''. Retrieved 2015-2-22.</ref>
== Accomplishments == Moncayo was selected as Asia’s Best Young Entrepreneur in 2009 by BusinessWeek magazine readers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/oct2009/gb20091025_371570.htm |title=Asia's Best Young Entrepreneur 2009: The Winner |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |accessdate=24 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106072641/http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/oct2009/gb20091025_371570.htm |archivedate=6 January 2011 |df= }}</ref> being the first non-Asian to receive this honor. He was also named Business Man of the Year by the Ecuadorian Chinese Chamber of Commerce in 2009.
Moncayo is the youngest permanent member of the World Entrepreneurship Forum,<ref>[http://www.world-entrepreneurship-forum.com/About-us/Members/Moncayo-Carlos "Carlos Moncayo"] World Entrepreneurship Forum. Retrieved 2015-2-22.</ref> an invitation-only global [[think tank]] under the patronage of French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] where 100 prominent entrepreneurs, academicians and political decision makers from across the globe offer recommendations on how to foster entrepreneurship.
In 2010, he was selected New York City Venture Fellow,<ref>[http://www.nyc.gov/html/om/html/2010b/pr494-10.html MAYOR BLOOMBERG ANNOUNCES NYC VENTURE FELLOWS PROGRAM"] ''News from the BLUE ROOM''. Retrieved 2015-2-22.</ref> a program founded by New York City Mayor, Michael Bloomberg, targeted towards assisting rising international entrepreneurs to develop scalable businesses with global impact. He is the youngest Latin American CEO to join the G-50 (Grupo de los Cincuenta) forum. In 2012, he was named [[List of Young Global Leaders|Young Global Leader]] by the World Economic Forum.
Moncayo has also been featured on ''Ideas Exchange'', a series from the [[BBC]] that pairs up business leaders from around the world to discuss the business landscape and their secrets to success. He was paired on an episode with Argentine-Spanish entrepreneur Martin Varsavsky.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0jbkWEZbTQY "Martin Varsavsky and Carlos Moncayo - Ideas Exchange - BBC"] ''BBC Worldwide''. Retrieved 2015-2-22.</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''Certified Public Manager₢''' (CPM) is a [[United States]] [[Professional certification|professional designation]] established in 1979 for the purpose of improving performance and advancing [[best practice]] standards for [[public sector]] managers. The CPM is a comprehensive [[management]] development program based upon a selected set of [https://web.archive.org/web/20121002043339/http://www.aspaonline.org/scpm/competencies.html competencies]. The CPM is awarded upon completion of a CPM program accredited by the National Certified Public Manager Consortium. CPM graduates come from public, private, and non-profit career fields. The words "certified public manager" are registered service marks by the [[U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]].
== Requirements ==
Requirements for the CPM vary by program, but all require at least 300 hours of training, including classes, application projects, structured readings, and examinations. Each CPM candidate is required to pass a series of courses centering on various management principles. The courses are designed around a set of core competencies and each CPM program requires an evaluation of all major [[curriculum|curricular]] competencies.
=== Curriculum competencies ===
The following competencies are present in all CPM curriculum:<ref>{{cite web|title=CPM Curriculum)|url=http://www.cpmconsortium.org/Curriculum|publisher=National CPM Consortium|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Competency !! Description |- | Personal and Organizational Integrity || Increasing awareness, building skills and modeling behaviors related to identifying potential [[Ethics|ethical]] problems and [[Conflict of interest|conflicts of interest]]; appropriate workplace behavior; and legal policy |- | Managing Work || Meeting organizational goals through effective planning, prioritizing, organizing and aligning human, financial, material, and information resources. Empowering others by [[Delegation|delegating]] clear job expectations; providing meaningful feedback and coaching; creating a motivational environment and [[Performance measurement|measuring performance]]. Monitoring workloads and documenting performance. Dealing effectively with performance problems. |- | Leading People || Inspiring others to positive action through a clear vision; promotes a [[Diversity (business)|diverse workforce]]. Encouraging and facilitating cooperation, pride, trust, and group identity; fostering commitment and team spirit. Articulating vision, ideas, and facts in a clear and organized way; effectively managing emotions and impulses. |- | Developing Self || Demonstrating commitment to continuous learning, self-awareness, and individual performance planning through feedback, study, and analysis. |- | Systemic Integration || Approaching planning, decision making, and implementation from an enterprise perspective; understanding internal and external relationships that impact the organization. |- | Public Service Focus || Delivering superior services to the public and internal and external recipients; including customer/client identification expectations, needs, and developing and implementing [[paradigm]]s, processes, and procedures that exude a positive spirit; demonstrating agency and personal commitment to quality. |- | Change Leadership || Acting as a change agent; initiating and supporting change within the organization by implementing strategies to help others adapt to changes in the work environment, including personal reactions to change; emphasizing and fostering [[creativity]] and [[innovation]]; being proactive. |}
The structure of CPM competencies arise from a [[holistic]] approach to management. Communication, organizational management, and ethical principles are emphasized as well as financial responsibility and effective [[change management]]. [[System thinking]] is introduced within the CPM program to emphasize the importance of broad open system management within organization. The program also places importance on personal development and change leadership.
== History ==
The idea for the CPM began in the early 1970s at the [[University Of Georgia|University of Georgia]] with the realization that the state was experiencing explosive growth in information and knowledge, significant new social legislation, and rapidly altering social values. During this time the [[Carl Vinson Institute of Government]] and the Georgia [[Merit system|Merit System]] were offering management training to public employees. It was recognized that these two organizations were offering duplications of training in some areas of management and were failing to meet the needs of other management areas. In 1974 University of Georgia’s Institute of Government, the Georgia Center for Continuing Education, and the Georgia State Merit System for Personnel Administration convened to discuss ways to broaden and refine Georgia state management training programs to meet the challenges of rapid change in the state and society. A consensus was reached that management in the state government needed to become more professional.<ref name=history>{{cite book|last=Patterson|first=Thomas H.|title=The History of the Certified Public Manager|date=8 April 2003|publisher=American Academy of Certified Public Managers|pages=1–38|url=http://www.cpmacademy.org/publications/AACPM_History_20030329.pdf|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref>
Ken Henning is considered the father of the CPM. He observed that most state training programs consisted of separate courses in which content was varied and lacked consistent focus. Henning felt that an integrated program would achieve a more organized approach to competencies needed by management. The CPM program was modeled after the [[Certified Public Accountant|CPA program]], consisting of the creation of a coordinated program addressing specific and various training needs relevant to management as well as with content involving study and preparation, practice and application of learning, examination, and prestigious recognition. The CPM would also involve the eventual creation of the American Academy of Certified Public Managers similar to the [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] as a central capstone organization.
Planners believed that awarding certificates of attendance were insufficient in the creation of a program based on quality. Early planners for the CPM determined that an innovative and rigorous program of study, application of knowledge, examination, and certification should be developed. University courses and the Georgia Merit System collaborated to reduce training duplication, and maximize efforts. Initially a program was developed in which six courses would be taught, three by the Georgia Merit System and three by the University of Georgia. After a series of meetings, two long-term goals for the CPM were created:
* To achieve and subsequently to maintain a level of national recognition for the CPM designation similar to that accorded the Certified Public Accountant (CPA) designation; and * To foster and encourage the highest possible levels of competence and ethical practice by managers in state and other levels of government through a national body of professionally trained and oriented Certified Public Managers.
After gathering strong support for the CPM program from the governor, legislative leadership, top management of state agencies, [http://www.uga.edu/ University of Georgia], regional intergovernmental personnel assistance (IPA) offices of the [[U.S. Civil Service Commission]], the [http://www.cviog.uga.edu/ University of Georgia’s Institute for Government and Center for Continuing Education] and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20110708103007/http://gms.georgia.gov/00/article/0%2C2086%2C683909_6170_11788934%2C00.html Georgia State Merit System of Personnel Administration] co-authored a detailed proposal.
February 9, 1976 the [[Georgia House of Representatives]] passed Resolution Act No. 97 in response to [[George Busbee|Governor Busbee]]’s request authorizing and directing the State Personnel Board and the State Merit System of Personnel Administration to implement the Certified Public Manager Program in the State Government of Georgia. On February 19, 1976 the Senate adopted the resolution and the legislature unanimously passed the resolution on February 26, 1976. On March 1, 1976 the CPM was formally established.
In 1977 the Georgia Society of Public Managers was created affiliated with a national organization to be known as the American Academy of Certified Public Managers. In 1980 the National CPM Consortium was developed with the completion of its constitution. The National CPM Consortium included [[Arizona]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. State)|Georgia]], [[Louisiana]], [[North Carolina]], and [[Vermont]]. The role of the CPM Consortium is to direct the general nature in which each program should operate, but it is not designed to dictate curriculum or administrative specifics for each program. Since then, the CPM program has expanded across the United States.
== National Certified Public Manager® Consortium ==
On October 6, 1980 the Certified Public Manager Board ratified the constitution of the [http://cpmconsoritum.org National Certified Public Manager® Consortium]. The Consortium is designed to monitor [[accreditation]] standards and facilitate program development of CPM programs around the nation.
== Program linkages ==
The CPM is linked with several professional organizations, including the [http://www.cpmacademy.org/ American Academy of Certified Public Managers], an organization for individuals with CPM accreditation and the [[American Society for Public Administration|American Society for Public Administration (ASPA)]], which provides free membership for CPM graduates. Annually, the [[Texas]] CPM and ASPA host a CPM/ASPA conference. In 2007 a new ASPA section called the Section on Certified Public Management was created to promote professional development and training regarding ethical values and technical competencies associated with outstanding public service. In addition, the SCPM holds conferences, forums, seminars, and discussion events.<ref>{{cite web|title=The William P. Hobby Center for Public Service|url=http://www.txstate.edu/cpm/|publisher=Texas State University - San Marcos|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref>
The Texas CPM program is designed to match professional development with the educational standards of [[International City/County Management Association|ICMA]].<ref>{{cite conference|url=http://andromeda.rutgers.edu/~ncsds/spaa/images/stories/documents/SPAA/Howard_Balanoff.pdf|title=An Introduction to the Certified Public Manager (CPM) Program: A Relevant Model for the Professional Development and Education of International Public Administrators and Not for Profit Managers|first=Howard R.|last=Balanoff|author=|authorlink=|author2=Marilyn K. Balanoff|date=8–9 June 2008|conference=Sino-U.S. International Conference on Public Administration|conferenceurl=|editor=|others=|volume=|edition=|booktitle=|publisher=|location=Newark, NJ|pages=|format=|id=|isbn=|bibcode=|oclc=|doi=|accessdate=|quote=|ref=|separator=|postscript=|language=|page=|at=|trans-title=}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== International expansion ==
In 2010 CPM began the first stage of international expansion by creating a CPM credential program for the [http://www.canadian-universities.net/World_Universities/Sweden-Swedish-National-Defence-College.html Swedish National Defense College].<ref>{{cite web|title=Swedish National Defense College CPM Program|url=http://www.txstate.edu/cpm/schedules/sndc-cpm.html|accessdate=10 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930071226/http://www.txstate.edu/cpm/schedules/sndc-cpm.html|archivedate=30 September 2012|df=}}</ref> The program will provide training for faculty, staff, and students in [[Sweden]] and the opportunity to attain CPM designation. The contract for the CPM program at the Swedish National Defense College was signed along with the [[William P. Hobby]] Center for Public Service which is affiliated with [[Texas State University - San Marcos]] and the National CPM Consortium. The program in Sweden is viewed as the first step toward more international expansion of the CPM.
In 2015, [http://professionallearning.nl/en Leiden University Centre for Professional Learning] in the Netherlands was the first international program to become a member of the National Certified Public Manager Consortium and be granted Associate status. Associate status grants authorization to develop an Accredited Certified Public Manager®<ref>{{cite web|title=2015 National CPM Consortium Annual Meeting|url=http://cpmconsortium.org/Consortium-News|website=cpmconsortium.org}}</ref> Program. Leiden intends to develop a pilot multi-country program serving the European Union.
== See also == * [[Accreditation]] * [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] * [[American Society for Public Administration]] * [[Professional certification]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links ==
American Academy of Certified Public Managers http://www.cpmacademy.org/
Good Governance Worldwide http://www.aspaonline.org/global
National Certified Public Manager® Consortium http://cpmconsortium.org [[Category:Public administration]] [[Category:Government occupations]]

revision.text:
'''Differential accumulation''' is an approach for analysing capitalist development and crisis, tying together mergers and acquisitions, stagflation and globalization as integral facets of accumulation. The concept has been developed by [[Jonathan Nitzan]] and [[Shimshon Bichler]]. The concept of differential accumulation emphasizes the powerful drive by dominant capital groups to beat the average and exceed the normal rate of return. This concept is tied to a definition of [[Capital (economics)|capital]] as a social category rather than a material category (as seen by [[Neoclassical economics|neo-classical]] thinkers). "[[Capitalism]] is not an ‘economic system’, but a whole social order, and its principal category of capital must therefore have an ‘encompassing’ definition."[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/9/ Differential Accumulation: Toward a New Political Economy of Capital.] Nitzan 1998, p. 175
...capitalization is a forward-looking process. What is being accumulated are claims on the future flow of profit. The pace of accumulation therefore depends on two factors: (a) the institutional arrangements affecting profit expectations; and (b) the normal rate of return used to discount them into their present value. The effect of rising industrial capacity on these factors is not only highly complex and possibly non-linear, but its direction can be positive as well as negative. But then if capital is not ‘tangible’, how should its accumulation be measured? Surely, the mere augmentation of money values tells us little about power, particularly in the presence of inflation or deflation. The answer is rooted in the relative nature of power. The power of the absentee owner is the power to control part of the social process, and that becomes meaningful primarily against the power of other owners.[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/9/ Differential Accumulation: Toward a New Political Economy of Capital.] Nitzan 1998, p. 204
== Regimes of accumulation == A firm can raise its profit through "breadth" by adding more employees to the organization. Conversely the firm can pursue "depth" by generating higher profit per employee. Each avenue of breadth and depth can be divided into pursuing differential accumulation through "internal" or "external" means. This gives us four categories of differential accumulation: internal breadth by [[Consolidation (business)|amalgamation]] (buy or join other businesses), external breadth through [[greenfield investment]] (build new factories), internal depth via [[Cost management|cost-cutting]] (make workers work harder or find ways to reduce the price of inputs), and external depth through [[stagflation]] (raise prices faster than the competition).[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/3/ Regimes of Differential Accumulation: Mergers, Stagflation and the Logic of Globalization.] Nitzan 2001, p. 232 {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! ! External ! Internal |- | '''Breadth''' | Green-field | Mergers & Acquisitions |- | '''Depth''' | Stagflation | Cost-cutting |} ===Dynamics of the regimes=== Nitzan and Bichler make several broad conclusions. (1) Of the four regimes, the most important are [[Consolidation (business)|amalgamation]] and [[stagflation]], which tend to oscillate inversely to each other. (2) Over the longer haul, amalgamation grows exponentially relative to green-field investment, contributing to the stagnation tendency of [[late capitalism|modern capitalism]]. (3) The wave-like pattern of [[mergers and acquisitions]] reflects the progressive break-up of socioeconomic ‘envelopes’, as dominant capital moves through successive amalgamation at the industry, sectoral, national, and, finally, global level. In this sense, they argue that the current global merger wave is an integral facet of differential accumulation. (4) Periodic lulls in amalgamation tend to be compensated for by stagflation, which appears as a crisis at the societal level, but which contributes significantly to differential accumulation at the disaggregate level. An end to the present worldwide merger boom could therefore trigger global stagflation. (5) [[Stagflation]] crises have been previously 'resolved' when dominant capital broke its existing envelope, pushing to amalgamate within a broader universe of takeover targets. Given that there is nothing more to conquer beyond the global envelope, Nitzan and Bichler argue that future stagflation crises may prove much more difficult to tame.[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/3/ Regimes of Differential Accumulation: Mergers, Stagflation and the Logic of Globalization.] Nitzan 2001, p. 233 == Stagflation in differential accumulation theory == Differential accumulation theory sees stagflation oscillate inversely with periods where [[mergers and acquisitions]] are dominant as a major strategy of dominant capital groups to "beat the market" or exceed the normal, average rate of return on investments. If too many people try to "beat the average" a market imbalance results. Stagflation, which appears as a crisis at the societal level, contributes significantly to differential accumulation at the disaggregate level, that is, of dominant capital groups accumulating faster than smaller businesses. Since the 20th century, the dominant capital group which has benefited from stagflation has been the "weapondollar-petrodollar coalition" during periods of Mid-east crises and rising oil prices. These periods have oscillated between periods of relative "peace" during which mergers and acquisitions have been the dominant strategy for beating the average. === Similarity to "supply shock" theories of stagflation === Differential accumulation theory shares some similarities with the "[[Stagflation#Supply_theory|supply shock]]" theory where there are sudden price changes due to a reduction in supply. One effect of cumulative mergers and acquisitions is that can result in concentrating the power to limit supply among fewer entities. The supply shock theory in political economy has focused mainly on the effect of [[OPEC]] (Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries) on the price of oil through the restriction of supply. This is similar to differential accumulation's look at the "weapondollar-petrodollar coalition" and OPEC. The similarity ends where differential accumulation places the cause of the price of oil in the creation of a global feeling of crisis and perceived scarcity because of conflicts in the Middle East, and not, as supply shock theories hold, on an actual reduction in supply. ==Deflation and the crisis of accumulation== Differential accumulation provides an alternative view to the [[Great Depression]] of the 1930s and the [[Global financial crisis of 2008–2009|global financial crisis of 2008 - 2009]]. Both of these crises are crises of deflation, and thus crises of accumulation. Businesses not only try to beat the average rate of accumulation, but struggle to avoid the threat of [[deflation]]. Deflation brings social destabilization and threatens capitalist accumulation. The overall debt burden of 2008 increases the deflationary threat over that from the Great Depression. Nitzan and Bichler state that the 2002 ratio of total debt to GDP in the US reached 290% - compared with 165% on the eve of the Great Depression. If prices begin to fall, they argue, firms will be unable to service their debt, which creates a risk of [[debt deflation]], chain bankruptcies, and the collapse of accumulation. "As the Great Depression unfolded falling nominal GDP caused the debt-to-GDP to soar to over 270%. a comparable drop now would push debt-to-GDP to over 400%".[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/203/ New Imperialism or New Capitalism?] Nitzan and Bichler 2006, p.69. Nitzan and Bichler argue that the Great Depression brought deflation, not inflation (at least from an aggregate viewpoint). Gardiner Means (1935) showed in his study of the US during this period: smaller firms with little market power saw falling prices and only a moderate drop in output. Large firms were able to keep their prices relatively stable, and even raise them in some cases, and let output fall by as much as 80%.[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/203/ New Imperialism or New Capitalism?] Nitzan and Bichler 2006, p.63. They stipulate that the primary cause of these crises is not financial but a crisis of differential accumulation. Inflation was helpful for not only providing differential accumulation but also to forestall the threat of deflation. Mergers had been in hibernation since early 2000s, which resulted in a greater reliance on the socially disruptive tool of inflation as stagflation. The soaring price of oil from 2004 to 2008 helped to sustain inflation, but with a looming threat of cheap manufactured goods from developing countries. Deflation in 2008 had become a looming threat.[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/251/02/20080515_bn_from_welltop_to_laptop_web.htm From Welltop to Laptop?] From Welltop to Laptop? 2008 Instead of focusing on the start of the US financial crisis, Nitzan and Bichler focus on [[Market_trend#Bear_market|bear markets]], the periods during which stocks (as measured in constant-dollars) were in a downward trend or where each successive peak is lower than the previous one.[http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/256/ Contours of Crisis: Plus ça change, plus c'est pareil?] Nitzan and Bichler 2009 By their reckoning a protracted Bear market has existed since 1999, which points to a much more entrenched accumulation crisis. Nitzan and Bichler argue that there is nothing automatic about the shifts between bear and [[Market_trend#Bull_market|bull markets]]. Each crisis has had a different solution. They identify a number of bear markets in the last century and the unpredictable solutions that shifted capitalism back to bull markets: * The crisis of 1905–1920 was resolved with a shift from robber-baron capitalism to large-scale business enterprise. * The crisis of 1928–1948 saw the rise of the [[John Maynard Keynes|Keynesian]] welfare-warfare state and large government. "Unregulated" capitalism ended. * The crisis of 1968–1981 saw neoliberal globalization, increasingly worldwide capital flows and the closing down of the Keynesian state. If the 2009 US stimulus package, the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009]] and proposed US budget are any indication, the 2008-9 crisis may see a return to the Keynesian state, at least for the United States. ==References== ==External links== * [http://bnarchives.yorku.ca Bichler and Nitzan Archives] * [http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/259/ Capital as Power: A study of order and creorder]. Nitzan, Jonathan and Shimshon Bichler. 2009. Routledge. ([http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/259/02/20090522_nb_casp_full_indexed.pdf Complete book available as free pdf].) * [http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/9/ Differential Accumulation: Toward a New Political Economy of Capital.] Nitzan, Jonathan. (1998). Review of International Political Economy. Vol. 5. No. 2. pp. 169–217. (Journal Article; English). * [http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/3/ Regimes of Differential Accumulation: Mergers, Stagflation and the Logic of Globalization.] Nitzan, Jonathan. (2001). Review of International Political Economy. Vol. 8. No. 2. pp. 226–274. (Journal Article; English). * [http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/203/ New Imperialism or New Capitalism?] Nitzan, Jonathan and Bichler, Shimshon. (2006). Review. Vol. XXIX. No. 1. April. pp. 1–86. (Journal Article; English) * [http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/251/02/20080515_bn_from_welltop_to_laptop_web.htm From Welltop to Laptop?] Nitzan, Jonathan and Bichler, Shimshon (2008) * [http://bnarchives.yorku.ca/256/ Contours of Crisis: Plus ça change, plus c'est pareil?] Bichler, Shimshon and Nitzan, Jonathan. (2009). Global Research. 1 January. (Magazine Article; English) [[Category:Capitalism]] [[Category:Macroeconomic theories]]

{{Primary sources|date=May 2012}} The '''Doctor of Commerce''' ('''DCom''')<ref>General information can be accessed via, for example, the [[South African Qualifications Authority|SAQA]] [http://regqs.saqa.org.za/search.php?cat=qual qualifications page] or the [[New Zealand Qualifications Authority|NZQA]] [http://www.nzqa.govt.nz/qualifications-standards/qualifications/ qualifications page] searching for "doctor of commerce".</ref> is a [[doctoral degree]] in [[commerce]]-, [[accounting]]-, [[economics]]-, and [[management]]-related subjects, awarded by universities in the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]]. The degree is offered both as a [[higher doctorate]], and as a [[research doctorate]].
The higher doctorate<ref>See for example the universities of [http://www.canterbury.ac.nz/regulations/award/dcom_regs.shtml Canterbury], [http://www.otago.ac.nz/courses/qualifications/dcom.html Otago], [http://clm.ukzn.ac.za/Libraries/Information_for_students/CLM_sflb.sflb.ashx Kwazulu-Natal], [http://courses.handbooks.uwa.edu.au/courses/c4/40910 Western Australia] and [http://www.wits.ac.za/files/gr264_189955001326275256.pdf Witwatersrand]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.</ref> is awarded for published work of the candidate, demonstrating original contributions of "special excellence" in some branch of commerce. The candidate will be a graduate of the university in question.
The research doctorate<ref>See for example the [http://www.univen.ac.za/management_sciences/manage_programmes.html University of Venda] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608233931/http://www.univen.ac.za/management_sciences/manage_programmes.html |date=June 8, 2012 }} and [http://www.unisa.ac.za/Default.asp?Cmd=ViewContent&ContentID=26739 UNISA].</ref> is largely comparable to a [[PhD]] and in fact "Doctor of Commerce" may refer to a commerce-related [[PhD]].<ref>See for example [http://www.victoria.ac.nz/vms/study/postgraduate/phd.aspx Victoria University of Wellington] and [http://www.nmmu.ac.za/default.asp?id=4882&aq=B%2B&fc=1400&bhcp=1 Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.</ref> Relatedly, at some universities the degree-title conferred will be a function of the candidate’s background: for example, in [[operations research]], the degree may be a PhD or a DCom, depending on whether the candidate held a [[Master of Science]] or [[Master of Commerce]] respectively.<ref>For example, at [http://www.unisa.ac.za/Default.asp?Cmd=ViewContent&ContentID=24967 UNISA], and the [http://www.univen.ac.za/management_sciences/manage_programmes.html University of Venda] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608233931/http://www.univen.ac.za/management_sciences/manage_programmes.html |date=June 8, 2012 }}.</ref> Further, in some cases, the degree title may also depend on the area of the research: a thesis focused on a more theoretical area (e.g. [[financial economics|"finance"]]) will be awarded a PhD, while one focused on a specific area or function (e.g. [[Managerial finance|financial management]]) will be awarded a DCom.<ref>For example, at the [http://www.uj.ac.za/EN/Faculties/ecofin/departments/fininvestman/coursesandprogrammes/postgraduate/Pages/5PhDinFinance.aspx University of Johannesburg] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106065404/http://www.uj.ac.za/EN/Faculties/ecofin/departments/fininvestman/coursesandprogrammes/postgraduate/Pages/5PhDinFinance.aspx |date=January 6, 2014 }}.</ref> Finally, in some cases the distinction will be whether the degree includes coursework or is entirely thesis based.<ref>For example, at the [http://web.up.ac.za/default.asp?ipkCategoryID=578&sub=1&parentid=40&subid=575&ipklookid=3 University of Pretoria] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227140522/http://web.up.ac.za/default.asp?ipkCategoryID=578&sub=1&parentid=40&subid=575&ipklookid=3 |date=December 27, 2013 }}.</ref>
The research doctorate is usually accessed following a [[Business education#Postgraduate education|related master's degree]], often the [[Master of Commerce]]. Here, there is generally a requirement that the [[master’s degree]] in question must include a research component, either comprising [[coursework]] with research, or being solely [[thesis]]-based.
==See also== * [[Business education #Doctoral]] * [[Doctor of Business Administration]] * [[Doctor of Management]] * [[Doctor of Public Administration]] * [[Master of Commerce]] * [[PhD in Management]] * [[List of fields of doctoral studies#Business Management.2FAdministrative Services|List of fields of doctoral studies: Business Management/Administrative Services]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Forrest Iandola | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = [[United States of America|American]] | fields = Computer Science | workplaces = | alma_mater = [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]] (B.S.)
[[University of California, Berkeley]] (PhD) | thesis_title = Exploring the Design Space of Deep Convolutional Neural Networks at Large Scale | thesis_year = 2016 | doctoral_advisor = Kurt Keutzer | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | footnotes = | spouse = Steena Monteiro {{Cite web|url=http://www.npcovenant.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/2015-Annual-Report-1.pdf|title=Annual Report, 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=North Park Covenant Church|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}} | religion = }} '''Forrest Iandola''' is an American [[computer scientist]] and [[entrepreneur]]. While a graduate student at [[University of California, Berkeley]], Iandola developed [[SqueezeNet]], a lightweight [[deep neural network]] that has been deployed on smartphones and other embedded devices. Iandola is the co-founder of [[DeepScale]], which develops energy-efficient [[deep learning]] technology for the automotive industry.{{Cite news|url=http://www.futurecar.com/article-2106-1.html|title=DeepScale Raises $15 Million for Perception Software for Autonomous Vehicles - FutureCar.com|website=www.futurecar.com|access-date=2018-04-07}} ==Early life and education== Iandola grew up in [[Pearl City, Illinois]], and he later attended high school at the [[Illinois Math and Science Academy]] (IMSA) in [[Aurora, Illinois]].{{Cite web|url=https://uofi150.news-gazette.com/people/forrest-iandola|title=University of Illinois {{!}} 150 Years|last=|first=|date=|website=The News-Gazette|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-07}}{{Cite web|url=https://digitalcommons.imsa.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=1020&context=commence_ceremony|title=Commencement of the Class of 2008|last=|first=|date=|website=DigitalCommons@IMSA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}} After graduating from IMSA in 2008, Iandola completed a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[computer science]] at [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] (UIUC) in 2012.{{Cite news|url=http://www.journalstandard.com/article/20120820/NEWS/308209939|title=Several local students graduate from U of I Urbana- Champaign|last=|first=|date=|website=Journal Standard|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://cs.illinois.edu/news/2-illinois-cs-students-win-honorable-mentions-cra-outstanding-undergraduate-researchers-award|title=2 Illinois CS Students Win Honorable Mentions for CRA Outstanding Undergraduate Researchers Award|last=Eade|first=Alyssa|date=|website=CS@Illinois|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}} Following that, Iandola completed a [[doctoral degree]] in electrical engineering and computer science at [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 2016.{{Cite thesis|last=Iandola|first=Forrest|title=Exploring the Design Space of Deep Convolutional Neural Networks at Large Scale|date=2016|degree=Doctorate|publisher=|url=http://oskicat.berkeley.edu/search~S1?/Xiandola&searchscope=1&SORT=D/Xiandola&searchscope=1&SORT=D&SUBKEY=iandola/1,3,3,B/frameset&FF=Xiandola&searchscope=1&SORT=D&1,1,|place=Berkeley, CA|doi=}} Retrieved 2018-04-07. ==Research== Forrest Iandola and his doctoral research advisor Kurt Keutzer published a series of papers on improving the speed, memory usage, and energy-efficiency of [[deep neural networks]].{{Cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=y1lVpBEAAAAJ|title=Forrest Iandola|last=|first=|date=|website=Google Scholar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}} In 2016, Iandola, Keutzer, and their collaborators published a deep neural network architecture called [[SqueezeNet]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.kdnuggets.com/2016/09/deep-learning-reading-group-squeezenet.html|title=Deep Learning Reading Group: SqueezeNet|last=Ganesh|first=Abhinav|date=|work=KDnuggets|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The idea behind SqueezeNet was to develop a smaller neural network with fewer parameters that can more easily fit into memory and can more easily be transmitted over a computer network. By 2017, SqueezeNet had become one of the standard neural architectures that is released as part of deep learning frameworks such as Caffe2, Apache [[MXNet]], and [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] CoreML.{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/caffe2/caffe2/blob/c63037fd27493d0db72debd8202776124fa46cb8/caffe2/python/tutorials/Model_Quickload.ipynb|title=SqueezeNet Model Quickload Tutorial|last=Inkawhich|first=Nathan|date=|website=GitHub: Caffe2|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}}{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/6dcb0ebb39558d83df4d9fd0338a46f775b94bd6/python/mxnet/gluon/model_zoo/vision/squeezenet.py|title=squeezenet.py|last=|first=|date=|website=GitHub: Apache MXNet|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}}{{Cite web|url=https://developer.apple.com/machine-learning/|title=CoreML|last=|first=|date=|website=Apple|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-10}} Companies including [[Baidu]], [[Imagination Technologies]], [[Synopsys]], and [[Xilinx]] have demonstrated SqueezeNet running on low-power processing platforms.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/09/26/baidu_mobile_deep_learning/|title=Baidu puts open source deep learning into smartphones|last=Chirgwin|first=Richard|date=2017-09-26|work=The Register|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.electronicsweekly.com/news/products/software-products/neural-network-sdk-powervr-gpus-2018-01/|title=Neural network SDK for PowerVR GPUs|last=Bush|first=Steve|date=2018-01-25|work=Electronics Weekly|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.engineerlive.com/content/deep-learning-computer-vision-algorithms-ported-processor-ip|title=Deep learning computer vision algorithms ported to processor IP|last=Boughton|first=Paul|date=2017-08-28|work=Engineer Live|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.embedded-vision.com/platinum-members/xilinx/embedded-vision-training/documents/pages/deep-learning-int8-optimization-xil|title=Deep Learning with INT8 Optimization on Xilinx Devices|last=|first=|date=|work=Embedded Vision Alliance|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} ==DeepScale== Iandola and Keutzer co-founded [[DeepScale]] in September 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/deepscale|title=DeepScale|last=|first=|date=|website=Crunchbase|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}} DeepScale is focused on bringing efficient deep learning to [[Advanced Driver Assistance Systems]] and [[Autonomous vehicles|Autonomous Vehicles]].{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/03/21/deepscale-raises-3-million-for-perception-ai-to-make-self-driving-cars-safe/|title=DeepScale raises $3 million for perception AI to make self-driving cars safe|last=Kolodny|first=Lora|date=2017-03-21|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} In 2018, DeepScale raised US $15 Million in Series A funding.{{Cite news|url=http://safecarnews.com/deepscale-attracts-15m-investment-to-advance-automated-vehicle-perception/|title=DeepScale attracts $15M investment to advance automated vehicle perception|last=|first=|date=2018-04-04|work=Safe Car News|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The funding round was led by two funds: [[Point72 Asset Management|Point72]], which is the personal fund of billionaire investor [[Steven A. Cohen]], and next47, which is a billion-dollar venture fund backed by [[Siemens]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.stamfordadvocate.com/business/article/Point72-invests-in-artificial-intelligence-firm-12805642.php|title=Point72 invests in artificial-intelligence firm|last=Schott|first=Paul|date=2018-04-04|work=Stamford Advocate|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2016/06/28/siemens-invests-in-new-startups-unit/|title=Siemens Will Put $1.1 Billion Into New Startups Unit|last=Orlowski|first=Ralph|date=2016-06-28|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} DeepScale has strategic partnerships with Tier-1 automotive suppliers including [[Visteon]] and [[Hella (company)|Hella Aglaia Mobile Vision GmbH]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1332816|title=Visteon Works with DNN Vanguard DeepScale|last=Yoshida|first=Junko|date=2018-01-09|work=EE Times|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1333147|title=Are We Short of Deep Learning Experts?|last=Yoshida|first=Junko|date=2018-04-03|work=EE Times|access-date=2018-04-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Iandola has been [[CEO]] of DeepScale since 2015. ==Honors and awards== Iandola received the National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate (NDSEG) Fellowship. This award funded the first three years of Iandola's doctoral research at University of California, Berkeley.{{Cite web|url=https://npre.illinois.edu/academics/scholarship/national-defense-science-and-engineering-graduate-ndseg-fellowship|title=National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate (NDSEG) Fellowship|last=|first=|date=|website=University of Illinois|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}} ==Personal life== Iandola is married to Dr. Steena Monteiro.{{Cite thesis|last=Monteiro|first=Steena|title=Statistical Techniques to Model and Optimize Performance of Scientific, Numerically Intensive Workloads (page vi)|date=2016|degree=Doctorate|publisher=|url=https://digitalcommons.usu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=6285&context=etd|place=|doi=}} Retrieved 2018-04-07. ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Iandola, Forrest}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Illinois]] [[Category:University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:Businesspeople]] [[Category:Computer scientists]] [[Category:American scientists]] [[Category:21st-century American scientists]] [[Category:Machine learning researchers]] [[Category:Computer vision researchers]]

revision.comment: Added construction details to history
revision.text:
{{Infobox library | library_name = Albert O. and Evelyn W. Foster Business Library | name_en = | library_logo = | image = | caption = | country = USA | type = | scope = | established = | ref_legal_mandate = | location = [[Foster School of Business]], [[University of Washington]] | coordinates = | branch_of = University of Washington Libraries | num_branches = | items_collected = | collection_size = | criteria = | legal_deposit = | req_to_access = | annual_circulation = | pop_served = | members = | budget = | director = | num_employees = | website = http://www.lib.washington.edu/business/ | phone_num = 206-543-4360 | references = }}
The '''Foster Business Library''' is the business [[library]] at the [[University of Washington]] in [[Seattle, Washington]]. As part of the university [[University of Washington Libraries|system of libraries]], it serves the 3,500 students, faculty, and staff of the [[University of Washington Michael G. Foster School of Business|Foster School of Business]]. The 21,500 square-foot facility, which opened in 1997, is located under a garden, beneath an {{convert|80|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} skylight, on two floors, connected with PACCAR Hall and adjacent to Dempsey Hall and the Bank of America Executive Education Center.
==Location== The library is located below-ground among the complex of buildings that comprise the [[Foster School of Business]]. The main entrance is located on the first floor of PACCAR Hall with an accessible entrance on the lower (basement) level. Previous to a 2009 renovation, the library's main entrance had been through the Bank of America Executive Education Center.
==Name == The library is named in honor of Albert O. and Evelyn W. Foster. A 1928 graduate of the University of Washington Business School, Albert Foster founded Seattle-based investment banking firm Foster & Marshall in 1938. Evelyn Foster was a 1932 graduate of the University of Washington. Albert and Evelyn were the parents of Michael G. Foster, for whom the Foster School of Business is named. Together, the Fosters established the Foster Foundation in 1984
== History == Made possible by a $3 million gift from the Foster Foundation in 1990, construction began in March 1995 with the library opening on June 23, 1997. A major renovation from 2009 to 2012 reoriented the library entrance through PACCAR Hall and increased seating and group study space.
==Inside Foster Library==
=== Hours === During the fall, winter, and spring quarters, the library is open Mondays through Thursdays from 8 a.m. to 11 p.m., on Fridays from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., 12 noon to 5 p.m. on Saturdays, and 1 to 5 p.m. on Sundays. Hours are extended during exam weeks and shortened during the summer quarter, university holidays, and between quarters.
===Study Areas=== Foster Library provides computers, printers, scanners, study tables, and reservable group study rooms equipped with flat-panel displays.
=== Collection === The Foster Library collection supports the study and practice of business management with books, periodicals, and research databases. The collection primarily includes material that supports professional practice and research in accounting, finance, management, marketing, information systems management, international business, operations management, and entrepreneurship. Complementary and similar materials are housed in other UW libraries, including [[Suzzallo Library|Suzzallo-Allen Libraries]], [[Odegaard Undergraduate Library]], and the libraries at [[University of Washington Bothell]] and [[University of Washington Tacoma]].
==External links== * [http://www.lib.washington.edu/business/] Foster Business Library * [http://www.lib.washington.edu/] University of Washington Libraries
[[Category:Business libraries]] [[Category:Library buildings completed in 1997]]
{{Washington-university-stub}}

[[File:FriedrichHonigmann.jpg|thumb|Friedrich Honingmann]] '''Friedrich Honigmann''' (2 March 1841 in [[Düren]] – 19 December 1913 in [[Aix-la-chapelle]]) was a German coal entrepreneur. He was founder of the mining company [[Sophia-Jacoba]] in Germany and co-founder of [[Oranje Nassau Mijnen]] in the [[Netherlands]]
==References== * {{aut|Visser, W.A.; Zonneveld, J.I.S.; Loon, A.J. van}}, 1987, Seventy-five Years of Geology and Mining in the Netherlands, Royal Geological and Mining Society of the Netherlands (K.N.G.M.G.), The Hague, Netherlands

revision.text:
[[File:WLANL - Quistnix! - Havenmuseum - Figee walkraan (1927).jpg|thumb|Crane by Figee, now at the [[Haven Museum]], [[Rotterdam]].]] '''Hendrik Figee''' ([[Haarlem]], May 28, 1838 – [[Haarlem]], December 3, 1907) was a Dutch businessman and entrepreneur creditted with growing the Haarlem factory [[Figee]] into an international manufacturer of [[crane (machine)|crane]]s.
==Biography== [[File:Spaarne - zicht naar het noorden vanaf brug.jpg|thumb|left|View of old Figee factory (center) on the [[Spaarne]] river, now converted to office space. On the left is the harbor master's office of Haarlem, and on the right is the old [[Droste factory]] building.]] He was the son of Hendrik Figee the elder who attended grade school and later became a surveyor. After passing his surveyor's exam, he went to work for his father in his steam engine factory on the Spaarne river. In 1866 he became full partner along with his brother Thomas and the company name changed to Gebroeders Figee (Figee brothers).<ref name=NNBW>[http://www.historici.nl/retroboeken/nnbw/#source=2&page=227 Hendrik Figee] biography in the [[NNBW]]</ref> He also helped start the crane manufacturing company Figee & De Kruyff in Amsterdam and the ironworks called the Haarlems IJzergieterij. In 1883 his brother Thomas bought the shipbuilding company Conrad on the other side of the Spaarne river. Werf Conrad had been named after the renowned Dutch engineer [[Frederik Willem Conrad]] (1800-1870). Figee wanted to make dredgers (baggermolens).<ref>[http://www.beeldbank.noord-hollandsarchief.nl/memorix/404be2c0-fb8f-11df-9e4d-523bc2e286e2 picture of Conrad dredger being let into the water] in 1910 on North Holland Archives</ref> The dredgers needed cranes on board, and these were supplied by Figee, which became a specialist in building cranes.<ref>[http://www.havenmuseum.nl/het-museum.collectieobject&cat_id=5&col_id=5 Crane]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} in the [[Haven Museum]], Rotterdam</ref> He was a member of the board of the [[Maatschappij voor Nijverheid en Handel, Haarlem]] from 1898-1902 and was also a member of the board of the Colonial Museum, formerly located in [[villa Welgelegen]].<ref name=NNBW/>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Figee, Hendrik}} [[Category:1838 births]] [[Category:1907 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Haarlem]]

revision.text:
'''Hu Yanyan''' ({{zh|c=胡妍妍}}) is the president and director of [[China Guardian]], the fourth largest auction house in the world. In 2015 she was named by the [[Financial Times]] as one of the five most powerful women in Asia’s art world<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/e0b36dae-c0c6-11e4-876d-00144feab7de|title=Asian women wielding art-world influence|last=Harris|first=Gareth|date=7 March 2015|website=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 March 2018}}</ref>.
== Early life and education == She graduated from [[Nankai University]] with a Master of [[museology]] <ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2015-03/20/content_19865892.htm|title=Hu Yanyan: the guardian of China Guardian|last=代艳|first=|date=|website=www.chinadaily.com.cn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 March 2018}}</ref>.
== Career == After completing her studies she worked as an editor for publications at the Beijing Municipal Administration of Cultural Heritage. She joined China Guardian in 1993 as a specialist in paintings and calligraphy <ref name=":1" />.
She launched the “Ancient Chinese paintings and calligraphy” auction category in 1998, and the “Chinese contemporary paintings and calligraphy" auction category in 2006 <ref name=":0" />, which has become the company's most popular category <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.artmediaagency.com/95660/profile-on-china-guardian-auctions-an-interview-with-ceo-hu-yanyan/|title=Profile on China Guardian Auctions: an interview with CEO Hu Yanyan {{!}} AMA {{!}} Art Media Agency|website=en.artmediaagency.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref>.
*
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags, these references will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}} [[Category:living people]] [[Category:Nankai University alumni]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]]

{{primarysources|article|date=September 2008}} {{Infobox Organization |name = International Foodservice Distributors Association |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = <!-- (map size, optional, default 200px) --> |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1969 |type = [[Industry trade group|Trade association]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] |location = |region_served = |membership = 145 |leader_title = President and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] |leader_name = Mark S. Allen, Jr.<ref>"[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3190/is_/ai_n6013801 IFDA names Allen president, chief executive]", ''Nations Restaurant News'' (April 26, 2004).</ref><ref>"[http://www.ifdaonline.org/webarticles/anmviewer.asp?a=342&z=38 Board of Directors]". International Foodservice Distributors Association.</ref> |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = <!-- (if any) --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.ifdaonline.org/ www.ifdaonline.org] |remarks = }} The '''International Foodservice Distributors Association''' ('''IFDA''') is a [[Industry trade group|trade association]] serving the [[foodservice distribution]] industry. Its members include foodservice distributors, foodservice manufacturers, and foodservice buying groups. Their largest membership base is from [[North America]], but IFDA represents the industry internationally as well. IFDA traces its history to 1906 when the National Wholesale Grocers' Association (NWGA) was founded to promote food safety and represent the industry to government. In 1969, IFDA was created as a division of NAWGA to represent the specific needs of foodservice distribution. Eventually, IFDA began independent operation on January 1, 2003.
==References== <references /> *"[http://www.ifdaonline.org/About-IFDA/What-IFDA-Does About IFDA]". International Foodservice Distributors Association.
==External links== * [http://www.ifdaonline.org/ International Foodservice Distributors Association]
[[Category:Industry trade groups based in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1969]]
{{business-org-stub}}

revision.text:
{{More footnotes|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Jerry Zucker |image = JerryZucker.jpg |image_size = 150px |birth_date = {{Birth date|1949|08|24|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Tel Aviv|Tel Aviv, Israel]] |death_date = {{Dda|2008|04|12|1949|08|24|mf=yes}} |death_place = [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]], [[South Carolina|SC]] |death_cause = [[Cancer]] |nationality = United States |children = Jonathan Zucker
Andrea Lee-Zucker
Jeffrey Zucker |alma_mater = [[University of Florida]] |known_for = [[Philanthropy]] |parents = Leon Zucker
Zipora Zucker |spouse = [[Anita Zucker]] (m. 1970 - 2008, his death) }} '''Jerry Zucker''' (August 24, 1949 – April 12, 2008) was an Israeli-born American businessman and philanthropist. ==Career== Zucker was president and CEO of the '''InterTech Group'''.{{cite web | url = http://www.postandcourier.com/article/20080413/PC1602/304139885 | title = Philanthropist Zucker dies | last = McDermott | first = John | publisher = The Post & Courier | date = 13 April 2008 | accessdate = 11 March 2016}} He was President and CEO of the '''Polymer Group''' at the time it acquired the [[Montreal]]-based [[Dominion Textile|Dominion Textile Company]] in 1997; he resigned from Polymer Group in 2003. In 2006, he acquired the [[Hudson's Bay Company|Hudson's Bay Company of Canada]], North America's oldest company, becoming its Governor (Company Chairman) and CEO. Zucker was also a part-owner of the [[South Carolina Stingrays]] of the [[ECHL]]. He ranked #354 on [[Forbes 400|Forbes 400 Richest Americans]] and #746 on [https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/10/G399.html Forbes Billionaire List 2006]. In 2008, Forbes placed his wealth at $1.2 billion [[USD]].{{cite web|url=http://www.charleston.net/news/2008/apr/13/philanthropist_zucker_dies |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414024343/http://www.charleston.net/news/2008/apr/13/philanthropist_zucker_dies/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 April 2008 |title=The Post and Courier - Charleston SC, News, Sports, Entertainment |publisher=Charleston.net |accessdate=14 December 2014 }} He held over 350 patents in his lifetime and donated millions of dollars to international medical missions as well as local charities.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/18/business/18zucker.html | title = Jerry Zucker, Industrialist and Inventor, Is Dead at 58 | date = 18 April 2008 | newspaper = New York Times | accessdate = 11 March 2016| publisher = The Associated Press }} ==Personal life== Jerry Zucker was born 24 August 1949 in [[Tel Aviv|Tel Aviv, Israel]], one of three children born to Leon Zucker and Zipora Zucker (née Shlifkovitz), the other two being his brother Jacob and his sister Rochelle. His parents were both [[Holocaust]] survivors. Zucker immigrated to the United States through [[Ellis Island]] in 1952.{{cite web | url = http://www.financialpost.com/story.html?id=443416 | accessdate = April 15, 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080414174716/http://www.financialpost.com/story.html?id=443416 | archivedate=April 14, 2008 | title = HBC's future cloudy after Zucker dead at 58}} As a child, he lived in South Carolina, Florida, and New Jersey, where he attended [[Jewish day schools]] his parents helped found. As a young man, Zucker attended the [[University of Florida]], majoring in Chemistry, Mathematics, and Physics. He later earned an M.S. in Electrical Engineering.{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/charleston/obituary.aspx?pid=107597187|title=Jerry Zucker|work=Charleston Post & Courier|accessdate=14 December 2014}} Zucker passed away from a [[brain tumor]] 12 April 2008.Marina Strauss, Zucker's death puts HBC fate in question, The Globe and Mail, April 14, 2008, p.B4{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/April2008/12/c5067.html|title=Hudson's Bay - HBC Announces Passing of Jerry Zucker|publisher=Newswire.ca|accessdate=14 December 2014}} Zucker was survived by his wife Anita, and by his children Jonathan Zucker, Andrea Muzin, and Jeffrey Zucker. At the time of his death, Zucker had been married to Anita Goldberg, his high school sweetheart, for 38 years. Together, they had three children: Jonathan, Andrea, and Jeffrey. Zucker lived most of his adult life in [[Charleston, South Carolina]] Ted Levin, president of the Emanu-el synagogue, said at Zucker's funeral: : "Anybody who reached out to him for help never went away with an empty hand....It's a loss not just for our community, or for [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]], but it's a loss for the world."{{cite web | url = http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/OBITUARIES/2008-06/1214701892 | title = Obituaries - Jerry L. Zucker | date = 29 June 2008 | accessdate = 14 March 2016}} ==Legacy== Shortly after Zucker's death, the [[Charleston County School District|Charleston County School Board]] decided to name a new [[North Charleston]] middle school in his honor. The Jerry Zucker Middle School of Science opened on August 24, 2008, which would have been Zucker's 59th birthday. The [[South Carolina Stingrays]], of which Zucker was part owner, adorned their helmets with a "JZ" sticker; the practice continues. The team also recognized his contributions to the team and the community by inducting him into the Stingrays Hockey Hall of Fame on March 21, 2009. The Stingrays organization unveiled the Jerry Zucker Community Service award, to be given annually to the Stingrays player who had the greatest impact on the local community. The first to receive the award was Stingrays [[Forward (ice hockey)|forward]] [[Spencer Carbery]]. The Jerry Zucker [[Ride for Hope]], started in October 2008, provides fundraising efforts for cancer research at the Hollings Cancer Center at the [[Medical University of South Carolina]]. In June 2009, Zucker's family made a donation of $2 million in Zucker's name to the [[Medical University of South Carolina]]. $1 million was allocated for the establishment of the Jerry Zucker Endowed Chair in Brain Tumor Research, an institution intended to support research and investigation into brain tumors. The remainder was used to support spinal cord research and provide neurological care and medical training in [[Tanzania]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch08/0408/arc04156112499.shtml Jerry Zucker] * [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch08/0408/arc04136109497.shtml Philanthropist Zucker dies] * [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch08/0408/arc04156114213.shtml Rays stay alive] * [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch08/0408/arc04296181115.shtml District to honor Zucker] * [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch09/0809/arc08248444249.shtml Grand opening event to be held] * [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch09/0309/arc03217713423.shtml Stingrays to honor Zucker] * [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch09/0609/arc06048069635.shtml Focus on a cure] * [http://www.gyaszhir.hu/Temak-jerry-zucker-51.html Jerry Zucker Hungarian Tribute] {{DEFAULTSORT:Zucker, Jerry (businessman)}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American people of Israeli descent]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in South Carolina]] [[Category:Deaths from brain tumor]] [[Category:Governors of the Hudson's Bay Company]] [[Category:Hudson's Bay Company people]] [[Category:Israeli businesspeople]] [[Category:Israeli emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Charleston, South Carolina]] [[Category:University of Florida alumni]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/John Hilton (manufacturer)|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''John Hilton''', ([[Circa|c.]] 1791 – 19 June 1866), was an English-born furniture manufacturer who is known to have been active in [[Montreal]] by 1808. He became one of the most successful businessmen in the city and the quality and quantity of his product gave confidence and impetus to a developing Canadian industry. His partner for a time, [[Edmond Baird]], was an important artisan in this competitive business. I think he was single all his life.
== External links == * [http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=4495 Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online'']
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hilton, John}} [[Category:1866 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]

Parthiban]] | successor4 = Idris Ahmad | constituency_AM4 = Ijok | assembly4 = Selangor State | majority4 = 1,920 (2008) | birth_name = Abdul Khalid bin Ibrahim | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|12|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Jeram]], [[Selangor]], [[Malayan Union]] (now [[Malaysia]]) | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = Salbiah Tunut | citizenship = [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[University of Malaya]]
