| signature = }} [[Malay styles and titles|Tan Sri Dato' Seri]] '''Abdul Khalid bin Ibrahim''' (born 14 December 1946) is a [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] politician who served as the 14th [[Menteri Besar]] (Chief Minister) of the state of [[Selangor]] from 2008 to 2014. He was elected to the [[Selangor State Assembly]] and the [[Dewan Rakyat|Parliament of Malaysia]] in 2008 and 2013 as a member of the [[People's Justice Party (Malaysia)|People's Justice Party]] (PKR), but became an [[independent (politician)|independent]] in August 2014, coinciding with his resignation as Menteri Besar. He was sacked from the party for his refusal to vacate his Selangor Menteri Besar post. ==Early life and business career== Khalid was born in the village of Kampung Jalan Raja Abdullah in [[Kuala Selangor]] district, Selangor. He graduated from the [[University of Malaya]] with a [[Bachelor's Degree]] in Economics and later obtained an [[MBA]] from the [[University of Queensland]].{{cite news | last = | first = | title = Fact boxes on Ijok (subscription required)| publisher = malaysiakini.com| date = 19 April 2007| url = http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/66177| accessdate = 20 April 2007}} Khalid began his career as a university lecturer. In 1979 he joined the [[United Malays National Organisation]] (UMNO), the leading party in Malaysia's ruling [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN) coalition.{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sacked-from-party-khalid-set-to-join-past-selangor-mbs-who-fell-from-grace |title=Sacked from party, Khalid set to join past Selangor MBs who fell from grace |date=10 August 2014 |work=Malaysian Insider |accessdate=27 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006083529/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sacked-from-party-khalid-set-to-join-past-selangor-mbs-who-fell-from-grace |archivedate= 6 October 2014 |df= }} In the same year, he became the chief executive of the government-controlled [[fund management]] firm [[Permodalan Nasional Berhad]] (PNB), a position he held until 1994. In 1981, he became famous for leading the "dawn raid" on the [[London Stock Exchange]], which resulted in PNB gaining a 51% share in British [[plantation]] concern Guthrie in less than two hours. He later became the CEO of the Malaysianized Guthrie, now known as [[Guthrie (Malaysia)|Kumpulan Guthrie Bhd]], from 1995 to 2003. ==Political career== In 2006, Khalid joined the opposition PKR, founded by the former deputy prime minister [[Anwar Ibrahim]], and became the party's treasurer-general. The party selected him as its candidate for a [[Ijok by-election, 2007|by-election]] for the [[Selangor State Legislative Assembly]] seat of [[Ijok]], which he lost to [[K. Parthiban]] of the [[Malaysian Indian Congress]] (MIC), a component party of the ruling [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN) coalition.{{cite news|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/node/170632|title=Khalid is Keadilan's pick for Ijok|date=18 April 2007|work=The Sun (Malaysia)|accessdate=26 September 2014}} In the [[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008 general election]], he contested the federal parliamentary seat of [[Bandar Tun Razak]] and re-contested the Selangor State Assembly seat of [[Ijok]]. He won both seats, while the opposition [[Pakatan Rakyat]] coalition made unprecedented gains and took a majority in the Selangor State Assembly. Khalid was appointed as the Menteri Besar of Selangor and was sworn in on 13 March 2008. He was the first person not of the BN coalition to hold the post.{{cite news|publisher=The New Straits Times |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20080313173454/Article/index_html |title=Khalid Ibrahim sworn-in as new Selangor Mentri Besar |date=13 March 2008 |accessdate=13 March 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314043108/http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/Thursday/NewsBreak/20080313173454/Article/index_html |archivedate=14 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In his first term, Khalid's government implemented a policy of delivering to each Selangor household an initial 20 cubic metres of water each year free of charge. The State Assembly also passed the country's first freedom of information legislation. It was in these areas—social policy and government transparency—that his administration was able to make the most progress. But in some cases, differences between the partners in the governing coalition, which included (the [[Democratic Action Party]] (DAP)) and the [[Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party]] (PAS)), proved difficult to reconcile.{{cite book|last=Harding|first=Andrew|title=The Constitution of Malaysia: A Contextual Analysis|year=2012|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=1847319831|chapter=Chapter 5}} For example, in 2009 Khalid rejected a move by PAS to draft legislation banning the sale of alcohol in Muslim-majority neighbourhoods.{{cite news|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne+News/Malaysia/Story/A1Story20090808-159869.html|title=Khalid: Alcohol sales to continue|last=Mazlinda Mahmood|date=8 August 2009|work=New Straits Times|accessdate=27 September 2014}} In the [[Malaysian general election, 2013|2013 general election]], Khalid's Pakatan Rakyat coalition increased its majority in the Selangor State Assembly, winning 44 out of its 56 seats. Though Khalid's PKR won fewer seats than the DAP and PAS, he retained the position of Menteri Besar.{{cite news|url=http://www.fz.com/content/ge13-pakatan-retains-selangor-44-seats|title=GE13: Pakatan retains Selangor with 44 seats|date=6 May 2013|work=fz.com|accessdate=27 September 2014}} In early 2014, PKR's national leader, Anwar Ibrahim, then a federal parliamentarian, sought to contest the Selangor State Assembly seat of [[Kajang]] in a [[Kajang by-election, 2014|by-election]]. The so-called "[[Kajang Move]]" would have allowed Anwar to oust Khalid as Menteri Besar with PKR's support. Anwar's conviction on a charge of sodomy caused Anwar's wife, [[Wan Azizah Wan Ismail]], to take over Anwar's presidency of PKR and the nomination as PKR candidate in the by-election instead, which she won. In July, the party nominated Wan Azizah as its preferred Menteri Besar.{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/no-surprise-as-pkr-endorses-wan-azizah-for-selangor-mb-post |title=No surprise as PKR endorses Wan Azizah for Selangor MB post |date=22 July 2014 |work=Malaysian Insider |accessdate=27 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140724035056/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/no-surprise-as-pkr-endorses-wan-azizah-for-selangor-mb-post |archivedate=24 July 2014 |df= }} The following month, Khalid was expelled from the party after he refused to comply with its direction for him to resign as the state's premier and make way for Wan Azizah.{{cite news|url=http://english.astroawani.com/news/show/khalid-ibrahim-expelled-from-pkr-effective-immediately-41585|title=Khalid Ibrahim expelled from PKR effective immediately|date=9 August 2014|work=Astro Awani|accessdate=27 September 2014}} Khalid sacked the PKR and DAP members of Selangor's [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]]-like Executive Council,{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/khalid-flexes-muscle-sacks-pkr-dap-excos|title=Khalid flexes muscle, sacks PKR, DAP excos|last=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal|date=12 August 2014|work=Malay Mail|accessdate=27 September 2014}} and continued to administer the state as an independent assemblyman with the remaining four councillors from PAS.{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/08/20/Selangor-MB-crisis-PAS-exco/|title=Selangor MB crisis: PAS exco member throws support behind Khalid|last=Ruban|first=A.|date=20 August 2014|work=The Star|accessdate=27 September 2014}} Khalid ultimately resigned on 26 August 2014, as it being clear that he could no longer command the confidence of the State Assembly.{{cite news|url=http://www.nst.com.my/node/26959|title=S’gor Sultan defers Khalid’s resignation until Pakatan names more candidates|last=Nuradilla Noorazam|date=26 August 2014|work=New Straits Times|accessdate=27 September 2014}} He remained in office while [[Sharafuddin of Selangor|Sultan Sharafuddin]] deliberated on whom to appoint as his replacement, before settling on PKR's deputy president [[Azmin Ali]], who was sworn in on 23 September 2014. After Azmin assumed office, the Sultan praised Khalid for leading the state "successfully and perfectly" and criticised the manner in which he had been ousted from the state's premiership by his own party.{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/khalid-was-a-wronged-man-says-sultan-of-selangor-in-surprising-speech|title=Khalid was a wronged man, says Sultan of Selangor in surprising speech|last=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal|date=26 September 2014|work=New Straits Times|accessdate=27 September 2014}} ==Election results== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; font-size:95%" |+ '''[[Selangor State Legislative Assembly]]'''{{cite web|url=http://semak.spr.gov.my/spr/laporan/5_KedudukanAkhir.php |title=Keputusan Pilihan Raya Umum Parlimen/Dewan Undangan Negeri |publisher=[[Election Commission of Malaysia]] |language=Malay |accessdate=4 February 2017 }} Percentage figures based on total turnout.{{Cite web | title = Malaysia General Election | work = undiinfo Malaysian Election Data | publisher = [[Malaysiakini]] | url = http://undi.info/# | accessdate = 4 February 2017}} Results only available from the [[Malaysian general election, 2004|2004 election]].{{cite web|url=http://keputusan.pru13.gov.my/5_KeputusanDR.php?kod=09800|title=Keputusan Pilihan Raya Umum Parlimen 2013|publisher=[[Election Commission of Malaysia]]|language=Malay|accessdate=6 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508211404/http://keputusan.pru13.gov.my/5_KeputusanDR.php?kod=09800|archivedate=8 May 2013|df=dmy-all}} !|Year !|Constituency !colspan=2|Government !|Votes !|Pct !colspan=2|Opposition !|Votes !|Pct !Ballots cast !Majority !Turnout |- |[[Ijok by-election, 2007|2007]] |rowspan=2|N11 [[Ijok (state constituency)|Ijok]], [[Selangor]] |{{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | |'''[[K. Parthiban]]''' ([[Malaysian Indian Congress|'''MIC''']]) |align="right" |'''5,884''' |'''59.33%''' |{{Party shading/Keadilan}} | |{{nowrap|Abdul Khalid Ibrahim}} ([[Parti Keadilan Rakyat|PKR]]) |align="right" |11,731 |52.91% |10,052 |1,850 |81.90% |- |[[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008]] |{{Party shading/Keadilan}} | |{{nowrap|'''Abdul Khalid Ibrahim'''}} ([[Parti Keadilan Rakyat|'''PKR''']]) |align="right" |'''7,196''' |'''57.70%''' |{{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | |Mohamed Sayuti Said ([[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]]) |align="right" |5,276 |42.30% |12,684 |1,920 |82.01% |- |[[Malaysian general election, 2013|2013]] |N46 [[Pelabuhan Klang (state constituency)|Pelabuhan Klang]], [[Selangor]] |{{Party shading/Keadilan}} | |{{nowrap|'''Abdul Khalid Ibrahim'''}} ([[Parti Keadilan Rakyat|'''PKR''']]) |align="right" |'''18,591''' |'''54.38%''' |{{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | |Nasarruddin M Zin ([[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]]) |align="right" |15,597 |45.62% |34,835 |2,994 |87.15% |} {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; font-size:95%" |+ '''[[Dewan Rakyat|Parliament of Malaysia]]''' !|Year !|Constituency !colspan=2|Opposition !|Votes !|Pct !colspan=2|Government !|Votes !|Pct !colspan=2|Others !|Votes !|Pct !Ballots cast !Majority !Turnout |- |[[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008]] |rowspan=3|P124 [[Bandar Tun Razak (federal constituency)|Bandar Tun Razak]] |{{Party shading/Keadilan}} | |{{nowrap|'''Abdul Khalid Ibrahim'''}} ([[Parti Keadilan Rakyat|'''PKR''']]) |align="right" |'''40,334''' |'''53.92%''' |{{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | |[[Tan Chai Ho]] ([[Malaysian Chinese Association|MCA]]) |align="right" |33,467 |44.74% |bgcolor=#BAB9B9 colspan="4"| |54,995 |2,515 |75.72% |- |rowspan=2| [[Malaysian general election, 2013|2013]] |rowspan=2 {{Party shading/Keadilan}} | |rowspan=2| {{nowrap|'''Abdul Khalid Ibrahim'''}} ([[Parti Keadilan Rakyat|'''PKR''']]) |rowspan=2 align="right" |'''44,067''' |rowspan=2|'''57.02%''' |rowspan=2 {{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | |rowspan=2| Tan Kok Eng ([[Malaysian Chinese Association|MCA]]) |rowspan=2 align="right" |32,235 |rowspan=2| 41.71% |{{Party shading/Independent}} | |Mohd Sukeri Abd Samat ([[Independent politician|IND]]) |align="right" |793 |1.03% |rowspan=2|78,157 |rowspan=2|11,832 |rowspan=2|85.89% |- |{{Party shading/Independent}} | |Mokhtar Salahudin ([[Independent politician|IND]]) |align="right" |191 |0.25% |} ==Honour== ===Honour of Malaysia=== * {{flagu|Malaysia}} : Commander of the [[Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia#Commander|Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia]] (P.S.M.) (1998){{cite web |url=http://www.istiadat.gov.my/index.php/component/semakanlantikanskp/|title=Semakan Penerima Darjah Kebesaran, Bintang dan Pingat}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mohamed Khir bin Toyo]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of Menteris Besar of Selangor|Menteri Besar of Selangor]]|years=13 March 2008 – 22 September 2014}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mohamed Azmin Ali]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Chief Ministers of Selangor]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Malay descent]] [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Malaysian Muslims]] [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Independent politicians in Malaysia]] [[Category:People's Justice Party (Malaysia) politicians]] [[Category:United Malays National Organisation politicians]] [[Category:People from Selangor]] [[Category:Members of the Dewan Rakyat]] [[Category:Members of the Selangor State Legislative Assembly]] [[Category:Selangor state executive councillors]] [[Category:University of Malaya alumni]] [[Category:University of Queensland alumni]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia]]

revision.comment: /* Founders */ link Joseph Oliver Carter
revision.text:
{{for|the film company of [[Alan Ladd, Jr.]]|The Ladd Company}} '''Ladd & Company''' was an early business partnership in the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. Its founders were '''William Ladd''' (1807–1863), '''Peter Allen (or Allan) Brinsmade''' (1804–1859), and [[William Northey Hooper]] (1809–1878). The company was behind the first commercial [[sugarcane]] [[Sugar plantations in Hawaii|plantation]] and first international land speculation in the [[Hawaiian Islands]].
==Founders== William Ladd was born May 11, 1807, in [[Hallowell, Maine]]. His father, John Ladd, sailed for South America and died about 1820. The younger Ladd married Lucretia Goodale (1807–1874) who was related to an earlier missionary to Hawaii, [[Lucy Goodale Thurston]]. Ladd's daughter Mary (1840–1908) married [[Joseph Oliver Carter]] (1835–1909), son of another Bostonian, Captain Joseph Oliver Carter (1802–1850), sister of diplomat [[Henry A. P. Carter]] (1837–1891).<ref>{{cite book |title= Joseph Oliver Carter: the founder of the Carter family in Hawaii, with a brief genealogy |publisher= Hawaiian Historical Society |year=1915 |page= 20 |author= George Robert Carter |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=E72RAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA20 }}</ref>
Peter A. Brinsmade was born April 1, 1804, in [[New Hartford, Connecticut]]. He graduated from [[Bowdoin College]] in 1826 and attended [[Andover Seminary]] 1826–1828 and [[Yale Theological Seminary]] 1828–1829.<ref>{{cite book |title= General catalogue of Bowdoin College and the Medical School of Maine, 1794-1912 |publisher= Bowdoin College |page= 75 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Jw9CAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA75 }}</ref> He married Elizabeth Goodale of Hallowell, Maine, sister of Lucretia in 1830.
William Northey Hooper was born October 16, 1809, in [[Manchester, Massachusetts]]. His father was sea captain William Hooper (1771–1809) and mother was Sally Northey. Hooper married Charlotte Augusta Wood.<ref>{{cite book |title= Hooper genealogy |editor= Thomas Hooper |year= 1908 |page= 206 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=PeZUAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA206 }}</ref>
The six sailed on the ''Hellespont'' from Boston in 1832. They arrived in [[Honolulu]] July 27, 1833.
==Hawaii== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Honoluluharboraerial.jpg|thumb|alt=aerial view of harbor|[[Honolulu Harbor]] today, site of Ladd & Co. 1833 store]] --> The first venture of Ladd & Co. was a store in Honolulu opened in July 1833. It was on a prime site of waterfront land at [[Honolulu Harbor]], coordinates {{coord| 21|18|37|N| 157|51|50|W| type:landmark_region:US-HI| display=inline| name= Ladd & Co. store }}. Because of Brinsmade's theological training, they were sometimes called the "Pious Traders". The partners erected a large stone house and other buildings that served as family housing, offices, and storage. They would first use a sunken ship's hulk as a wharf, and later build a more permanent one. The business, however, barely supported their families.<ref name="hjh98"/>
In 1835 Ladd & Co. leased {{convert|980|acre}} for a sugarcane plantation in [[Koloa, Hawaii|Kōloa]] on the island of [[Kauai|Kaua{{okina}}i]] from Royal Governor [[Kaikioewa]].<ref name="keeper">{{cite web |author= Darlene E. Kelley |title= Important People - Part 18. |work = Keepers of the Culture: A study in time of the Hawaiian Islands As told by the ancients |url= http://files.usgwarchives.net/hi/statewide/newspapers/importan39nnw.txt |date= August 10, 2008 |accessdate=2010-04-11}}</ref> The project had the support of conservative missionaries such as [[Hiram Bingham I]].<ref name="daughters">{{cite news |title= A Leaf in History: Showing how the government of the Hawaiian Islands was induced to perpetuate great wrongs against American merchants in aid of English merchants |publisher= [[Daughters of the American Revolution]] |work= Daughters of the American Revolution magazine |volume=6 |number=1 |date= January 1895 |pages=121–127 |author= Mary S. Lockwood |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YRcXAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA121 }}</ref>
Although sugarcane had been raised by [[ancient Hawaii]]ans on small personal plots, this was the first large-scale commercial production in Hawaii.<ref name="cushing">{{cite journal |hdl= 10524/508 |title= Beginnings of Sugar Production in Hawai'i |volume=19 |author= Robert L. Cushing |year= 1985 |pages= 17–34}}</ref> Joseph Goodrich of the [[Waiakea Mission Station-Hilo Station|Hilo mission]] and Samuel Ruggles of the [[Kahikolu Church|Kona Mission]] had experimented with using agriculture to support their missions as well as give employment to their students.<ref>{{cite journal |hdl=10524/84 |title=Sandwich Island Missionaries: The First American Point Four Agents |author=Merze Tate |work=Annual report of the Hawaiian Historical Society |year=1962 |publisher=Hawaiian Historical Society }}</ref> After trying unsuccessfully to get Rev. Goodrich to run the operation, Hooper moved to the land as manager, despite having no training in engineering nor agriculture.<ref name="cushing"/>
[[File:Kauai-old-sugar-mill-Koloa-chimney.JPG|thumb|left|alt=chimney ruin|Ruins of the [[Old Sugar Mill of Koloa|Ladd sugar mill]]]] The first planting was in September 1835, and although a small amount of [[molasses]] was produced in 1836, the wooden rollers in the mill were replaced with iron ones for increased production. By 1837, the mill produced over {{convert|4000|lb}} of sugar and {{convert|700|usgal|l}} of molasses . A subsequent mill, whose ruins are still visible, was built from 1839 to 1841. This [[Old Sugar Mill of Koloa|Kōloa Sugar Mill]] is now a [[National Historic Landmark]].<ref name="focus">{{cite web |title= Old Sugar Mill of Koloa nomination form |author= Benjamin Levy| work= National Register of Historic Places |date= August 1978 |publisher= U.S. National Park Service |url= {{NHLS url|id=66000296}} |accessdate=2010-03-08 }}</ref>
On April 13, 1839 Peter Brinsmade was appointed American consular agent after [[John Coffin Jones]]. This was originally an unpaid position of the lowest rank in the [[United States Department of State]]. In July 1844 he was promoted to the rank of [[Consul (representative)|Consul]]. William Hooper would act as deputy when Brinsmade was on his extended trip away from the islands. Their duties were reporting on commerce and protecting American citizens.<ref name="hackler08">{{cite news |hdl= 10524/342 |title= "Earnest Persuasion but Not Peremptory Demand:" United States Government Policy toward the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi, 1820–1863 |work= Hawaiian Journal of History |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume= 42 |author= Rhoda E. A. Hackler |year= 2008 |pages= 49–67}}</ref> Hooper sailed to Boston in 1840 but returned by May 1841.<ref name="diary"/>
In November 1841 the partners negotiated a much larger deal with [[William Richards (Hawaii)|William Richards]], a former missionary who was now a political advisor. The idea was to form a [[joint stock company]] to develop all unoccupied land in the kingdom. Richards thought that adding a clause that invalidated the agreement unless Hawaii continued to be an independent country would help investors pressure world powers to protect its government. Brinsmade traveled back to the United States trying to find investors. He could not get any takers. He then went to Britain, and then France. He met up with [[Timothy Haalilio|Timothy Ha{{okina}}alilio]] who was sent with Richards to negotiate for official recognition. Finally they seemed to find a partner in [[Belgium]]: Brinsmade convinced the [[Belgian colonial empire|Belgian Colonization Company]] headed by King [[Leopold I of Belgium]] on May 16, 1843, to sign a contract. The agreement would transfer stock in Ladd & Co. to the Belgian investors in exchange for a badly needed infusion of cash.<ref name="evidence"/>
Just then news arrived that the Hawaiian islands had been taken under a military occupation called the [[Paulet Affair (1843)|Paulet Affair]]. The clause that was supposed to help guarantee Hawaii's independence now made the deal grind to a halt. James F. B. Marshall, a young associate of Ladd & Co., had secretly made his way to London with letters from Kamehameha III presenting his side of the occupation. Brinsmade met him in London and desperately negotiated with the British foreign office. [[George Hamilton-Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen|Lord Aberdeen]] who was British [[Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs]], had been told by British Consul [[Richard Charlton (Hawaii)|Richard Charlton]] that Americans were granted a land monopoly. Brinsmade convinced Aberdeen that he would be happy to take investors from any country, using the Belgium contract as his proof. Finally on November 28, 1844, a joint declaration with Britain and France recognized Hawaii's independence. Marshall had returned to Hawaii while Richards and Ha{{okina}}alilio tried to get the United States to also recognize the Hawaiian Kingdom.<ref name="marshall">{{cite news |title= An unpublished chapter of Hawaiian History |work= Harper's magazine |author= James F. B. Marshall |volume= 67 |year= 1883 |pages= 511–520 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=-4UCAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA511 }}</ref> [[File:Saksen-Koburg Leopold-2a.jpeg|thumb|upright|alt=man in 19th-century European military uniform|[[Leopold I of Belgium|King Leopold]] was expected to be their investor]]
Brinsmade stayed in Europe trying to collect, but the investors were now wary. Meanwhile, Ladd & Co. was borrowing heavily to finance new facilities for its expected expansion. Some of this money came from the King himself. The U.S. State Department replaced Brinsmade as Consul during his absence in January 1845 by [[Alexander G. Abell]].<ref name="greer">{{cite news |hdl= 10524/441 |title= A. G. Abell's Hawaiian Interlude |work= Hawaiian Journal of History |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume= 29 |author= Richard A. Greer |year= 1995 |pages= 57–74}}</ref> For the first time, a diplomatic representative called "Commissioner", George Brown, also was appointed in March 1843, in addition to the trade representative.<ref name="hackler08"/> [[Gerrit P. Judd]], the Finance Minister of the Kingdom, realized the government itself was short of cash and called in their loan. Judd and Richards convinced the Hawaiian government to disavow the deal. At least one historian notes a factor in losing the support of the American Protestant missionaries was the fact that the Belgians were generally Catholic.<ref name="Simpson">{{cite news |hdl= 10524/142 |title= Sir George Simpson and the Mission for Hawaiian Independence 1840-1843 |work= Hawaiian Journal of History |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume= 20 |author= Richard MacAllan |year= 1986 |pages= 67–82}}</ref>
When a newspaper report on Ladd's shaky financial situation got back to Belgium, the investors pulled out of the deal for good. Brinsmade returned to Hawaii empty-handed in March 1846.
With no incoming cash, the Honolulu Ladd & Co. had shut down in November 1844. As the company liquidated, they felt they were owned money by the government, but the case required lengthy arbitration.<ref name="evidence">{{cite book |title= Report of the proceedings and evidence in the arbitration between the King and Government of the Hawaiian Islands and Messrs. Ladd & Co., before Messrs. Stephen H. Williams & James F. B. Marshall, arbitrators under compact |authors= [[John Ricord]], Stephen H. Williams, James F. B. Marshall |publisher= C.E. Hitchcock, printer, Hawaiian Government press |year= 1846 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=s2iW_IL-mlkC }}</ref> Both the British and Americans accused the Kingdom of being biased against them.<ref name="daughters"/>
Then Brinsmade sued newspaper publisher [[James Jackson Jarves]] for libel for publishing the story.<ref>{{cite book |title= History of the Hawaiian islands: embracing their antiquities, mythology |edition=3rd |author= [[James Jackson Jarves]] |pages=211–230 |publisher= C.E. Hitchcock |year=1847 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=r6RZeukWpXwC&pg=PA211 }}</ref> There was now an official Attorney General for the first time in Hawaii: [[John Ricord]]. However, several parties to the lawsuits did not recognize his authority, so this case was added to the arbitration. In June 1846 the new American Commissioner [[Anthony Ten Eyck]] arrived, who served as lawyer for the company. [[Joel Turrill]] took over as the new Consul. After many hearings, which were treated as entertaining theater by the Honolulu residents, Ladd & Co. gave up recovering anything.<ref name="greer"/> By October 1846 [[Charles Reed Bishop]] and [[William Little Lee]] arrived from New York. Lee would organize a court system and become its chief justice. Bishop would help sort out the accounts of Ladd & Co., then start Hawaii's first bank and inherit the largest landholdings in the islands.
==New speculation== The old Ladd store and house complex was auctioned off, and one of the new tenants was Robert Cheshire Janion, founder of what would become [[Theo H. Davies & Co.]] Part of their wharf was used by Charles Brewer of [[C. Brewer & Co.]] These became two of the "[[Big Five (Hawaii)|Big Five]]" corporations dominating the Hawaiian economy in later decades.<ref name="hjh98">{{cite news |hdl= 10524/430 |title= Along the Old Honolulu Waterfront |work= Hawaiian Journal of History |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume= 32 |author= Richard A. Greer |year= 1998 |pages= 53–66}}</ref> The Kōloa plantation was repossessed by the Hawaiian government and sold to Robert Wood, Hooper's brother-in-law, who ran it until 1874. It was purchased by the McBryde family in 1899, who operated it until shut down in 1996 as part of [[Alexander & Baldwin]].<ref>{{cite news |title= HC&S, last of sugarcane plantations, on track toward more financial losses |author= Andrew Gomes |date= November 15, 2009 |newspaper= [[Honolulu Advertiser]] |url= http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/Nov/15/ln/hawaii911150370.html |accessdate=2010-03-07 }}</ref>
Brinsmade published a few articles in a new newspaper called the ''Sandwich Islands News'' which had been started to counter Jarves' paper.<ref>{{cite book |title= Hawaiian National Bibliography, 1780-1900: 1831-1850 |chapter= Sandwich Islands News |author= David W. Forbes |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year=2000 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=dXCTq8YEw7IC&lpg=PA488&pg=PA487 |isbn= 978-0-8248-2379-5 }}</ref> Brinsmade sailed to San Francisco as part of the [[California Gold Rush]], where he worked for newspapers and attempted various businesses for prospectors. He returned to Massachusetts where he died October 6, 1859.
Hooper also sailed to San Francisco in November 1848<ref name="diary">{{cite web |title= Finding Aid for the Diaries of William Hooper |publisher= Kauai Historical Society, Lihue, Kauaʻi, Hawaii |url= http://www.kauaihistoricalsociety.org/assets/finding_aids/manuscript_22__william_hooper_diaries.pdf }}</ref> and worked for Cross, Hobson & Co. where he died on December 31, 1878.
Ladd died February 8, 1863, in Honolulu.<ref name="laddobit">{{cite news |title= Funerals |newspaper= Sailor's Magazine |page=310 |date= June 1864 |volume= 36 |number= 10 |publisher= [[American Seamen's Friend Society]] |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=eNkaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA310 }}</ref> Ladd and his brother, John Ladd, who died October 11, 1859, were buried in [[Oahu Cemetery]].<ref>{{cite journal |hdl= 10524/384 |title= Here Lies History: Oahu Cemetery, a Mirror of Old Honolulu |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume=1 |author= Richard A. Greer |year= 1967 |pages= 53–71}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Relations between the Kingdom of Hawaii and the United States]] * [[United States Minister to Hawaii]] * [[Sugar plantations in Hawaii]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |title= Koloa plantation, 1835-1935: a history of the oldest Hawaiian sugar plantation |author= Arthur Chambers Alexander |year=1937 |publisher= Honolulu Star-Bulletin }} * {{cite book |title= Imperial Maine and Hawai'i: Interpretative Essays in the History of Nineteenth Century American Expansion |chapter= Peter Allen Brinsmade and the Tragic Pursuit of a Pious Capitalism |author= Paul T. Burlin |pages=21–56 |year=2008 |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |isbn= 978-0-7391-2718-6 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LRY8khcvxqEC&lpg=PA54&pg=PA21 }}
==External links== * {{cite web |title= Ladd & Company: Koloa Plantation - Hawaii's First Sugar Plantation |work= Ladds of New England web site |author= Merle G. Ladd |url= http://www.laddfamily.com/Files/Hawaii.htm |accessdate=2010-03-01 }}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ladd and Co.}} [[Category:Sugar plantations in Hawaii]] [[Category:Kauai County, Hawaii]] [[Category:1833 establishments in Hawaii]] [[Category:Business in Hawaii]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox magazine | logo = | image_size = 245px | image_file = Le-Commerce-du-Levant-September-2014.jpg | image_caption = Cover of ''Le Commerce du Levant'' (September 2014) | editor_title = | editor = | category = Business magazine | frequency = Monthly | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | circulation_year = | total_circulation = | founder = Toufic Mizrahi | founded = 1929 | firstdate = | country = Lebanon | based = [[Beirut]] | language = French | website = | issn = | Founded by = Toufic Mizrahi }} '''''Le Commerce du Levant''''' is a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] monthly economic magazine published in [[French language]] in Lebanon covering various aspect including economy, commerce, industry, tourism, banking and finance.
==History and profile== ''Le Commerce du Levant'' was established in 1929.<ref name="Eur2002">{{cite book|title=The Middle East and North Africa 2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4CfBKvsiWeQC&pg=PA738|accessdate=17 September 2016|date=31 October 2002|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-85743-132-2|page=738}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Le Commerce du Levant|url=http://www.beirut.com/l/5415|work=Beirut|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> The headquarters is in [[Beirut]].<ref name="Eur2002"/><ref name="pub"/> It was formerly published on a weekly basis.<ref name="Eur2002"/> The magazine is published monthly by Société de presse et d’édition libanaise S.A.L.<ref name="pub"/> that also publishes the French Lebanese daily ''[[L'Orient-Le Jour]]''. Nayla de Freige is the president-director general of the publication.
The magazine covers articles about business and commerce related to both Lebanon and the [[Middle East]].<ref name=pub>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/uk/media-solutions/factsheet/mediadata/le-commerce-du-levant/?PARAM1=SBOCB1#.V90p1pOLQxc|title=Le Commerce du Levant|work=Publicitas|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.lecommercedulevant.com/ Official website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Commerce du Levant, Le}} [[Category:Business magazines]] [[Category:French-language magazines]] [[Category:Lebanese magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1929]] [[Category:Media in Beirut]] [[Category:Monthly magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]]
{{business-mag-stub}}

revision.comment: clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Merchant’s → Merchant's (2)
revision.text:
{{about|the Lowertown district|Downtown Saint Paul as a whole|Downtown Saint Paul}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Lowertown Historic District | nrhp_type = hd | nocat = yes | image = Lowertown HD 3.jpg | caption = Commercial buildings of the Lowertown Historic District | alt = A row of commercial buildings lit by early morning light | locmapin = Minnesota#USA | map_alt = Located in Minnesota in downtown Saint Paul | coordinates = {{coord|44|56|57|N|93|5|13|W|display=inline}} | location = Roughly bounded by Kellogg Blvd, Broadway, 7th, and Jackson Sts., [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]] | area = {{convert|35.5|acre|ha}} | built = 1870–1921 | architect = Multiple | architecture = Late 19th and 20th Century Revivals, Late Victorian | refnum = 83000935<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2007a}}</ref> | governing_body = Local | added = February 21, 1983 }}
The '''Lowertown Historic District''' is a [[Historic districts in the United States|historic district]] in the Lowertown neighborhood of [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]], United States. This 16-block warehouse and wholesaling district comprises 37 [[contributing properties]] built 1870s–1920. It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1983 for the significance of its river and rail connections, economic impact, architecture, and urban planning.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Murphy |first=Patricia |author2=Susan Granger |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration Form: Lowertown Historic District |url=http://nrhp.mnhs.org/nomination/83000935.pdf |publisher=National Park Service |date=1981-11-30 |accessdate=2013-04-27}}</ref> Lowertown was originally the lower landing on the [[Mississippi River]]; the first port of access to the [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul|Twin Cities]]. Several warehouse, railroad, banking, and distribution buildings served the entire [[Upper Midwest]] from 1880 to 1920. A significant concentration of these buildings survive, unified by similar architectural styles and construction materials. Many were designed by the city's most prestigious architects, including Cass Gilbert and Clarence Johnston, Sr.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lowertownlanding.com/lowertown-building-history/|title=Lowertown History |publisher=Lowertown Landing |date= |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref>
==History== The Lowertown neighborhood declined after the Depression. The renovation of the Merchant's National Bank Building (now McColl Building) in the late 1960s was the first project to focus attention on revitalization potential. The conversion of the Noyes Brothers and Cutler Building into a complex of offices, shops, and restaurants (now known as Park Square Court) soon followed. The city's Housing and Redevelopment Authority (HRA) became involved in 1973 when Mears Park was redesigned by William Sanders and renamed after Norman B. Mears, a Saint Paul businessman.
In April, 1978 the Lowertown Redevelopment Corporation (LRC) was organized with the goal of creating “a place for people, a highly livable urban village in the midst of the city, which will bring new jobs, housing, commercial development, and year round activities to Lowertown and infuse the city with renewed vitality.”<ref>http://lowertownsaintpaul.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/full-lowertown-master-plan2.pdf</ref> Enabled by an unprecedented $10 million grant by the McKnight Foundation, the LRC assumed the role and responsibility of driving the revitalization of Lowertown. Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, artists moved to Lowertown, attracted by low rents, raw space and relative quiet. This new population began to bring life to the buildings and the streets of Lowertown. Initiated by the LRC and supported fully by the City of St. Paul, Lowertown was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1983;<ref>http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/natregsearchresult.do?fullresult=true&recordid=54</ref> the next year, the City of St. Paul designated the Lowertown Historic District as a Heritage Preservation Site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stpaul.gov/index.aspx?NID=4338&ART=7988&ADMIN=1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127025950/http://www.stpaul.gov/index.aspx?NID=4338&ART=7988&ADMIN=1 |archivedate=2013-01-27 |df= }}</ref>
==Redevelopment== Aided by these designations and the associated tax credits, Artspace, the LRC, the City and others partnered to renovate three buildings dedicated to the arts. The Lowertown Artists Lofts Cooperative, the Tilsner and the Northern Warehouse were renovated and became the anchors for the arts community.{{when|date=May 2017}} Throughout the years, there has been a steady commitment to incrementally reinvest in the assets of Lowertown. Instead of demolishing and building new, Lowertown remained committed to a slow, deliberate and steady approach to redevelopment. This approach allowed Lowertown to remain a relatively quiet neighborhood on the edge of downtown. Such an approach was particularly supportive of the artist community, as it respected the financial and environmental needs of working artists. In 1982, the St. Paul Farmers’ Market moved to Lowertown. An institution since the late 1800s, the Farmers’ Market was an anomaly of sorts for Lowertown - it was a destination in the middle of a relatively quiet neighborhood. The market now draws 20,000 people each weekend in the summer. In 2006 the LRC transformed into the Lowertown Future Fund to continue supporting Lowertown redevelopment.
New residences have been built in the neighborhood, attracting new residents paying market rate for condominiums. Restaurants, festivals, weddings and other regional attractions, such as the restored Union Depot, have opened in Lowertown. (Greater Lowertown Master Plan, 2011)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lowertownlanding.com/lowertown-redevelopment/|title=Lowertown Redevelopment |publisher=Lowertown Landing |date= |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref> The [http://www.stpaulartcrawl.org/ St. Paul Art Crawl] is held twice a year (Spring and Fall) and exemplifies the cultural atmosphere that local residents have worked so hard to maintain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://loftsatfarmersmarketblog.com/2011/12/27/st-paul-art-crawl-april-27-29th/|title=Annual Art Crawl |publisher=LFM |date= |accessdate=2011-12-27}}</ref> In late 2013, USA Today named Lowertown 1 of "10 up-and-coming neighborhoods around the USA" <ref>https://www.usatoday.com/experience/america/best-of-lists/10-up-and-coming-neighborhoods-to-explore-this-summer/8814935/</ref> after it was announced RealtyTrac named Lowertown at the top of its "hipster zip codes" list.<ref>http://www.realtytrac.com/Content/news-and-opinion/top-25-hipster-zips-for-returns-on-rental-properties-7940</ref> The "hipster" designation implies the neighborhood's high proportion of "people between 25 and 34 years old who use public transportation and rent their housing." <ref>http://www.twincities.com/localnews/ci_25730731/hipster-rebirth-st-pauls-lowertown-noted-usa-today</ref>
In 2015, the [[St. Paul Saints]] professional baseball team opened its season in the new [[CHS Field]]. The stadium stands in the space of the former Gilette/Diamond Products plant at 5th Street and Broadway. Designs for the stadium were presented to the public in December 2013.<ref>http://www.twincities.com/stpaul/ci_24662098/st-paul-saints-ballpark-designs-unveiled</ref> Art installations from local artists adorn the exterior of the ballpark. Despite its name, the CHS Field sits outside the official 18 blocks that make up the Lowertown Heritage Preservation District, roughly bound by Kellogg Boulevard, Broadway, 7th Street and Jackson Street.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stpaul.gov/DocumentCenter/Home/View/20504 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811204331/http://www.stpaul.gov/DocumentCenter/Home/View/20504 |archivedate=2014-08-11 |df= }}</ref>
==Mears Park== [[File:Mears Park in downtown Saint Paul MN.jpg|thumb|Image of Mears Park, 2017]] [[File:Mears Park, Lowertown St Paul Clock 433125593 o.jpg|thumb|Mears Park, Lowertown St Paul Clock]] Previously known as Smith Park, Park Square, and Baptist Hill, Mears Park is bounded by 5th, 6th, Sibley and Wacouta streets. The site was originally the home of the First Baptist congregation, who built their church on top of a hill in the middle of a city block. In 1849 the land was donated to the city by a man named Robert Smith after the church expanded to a new location a few blocks north. The hill was leveled and the square was formally created in 1888.<ref name="millet">{{cite book|last1=Millet|first1=Larry|title=AIA Guide to Downtown St. Paul|date=2010|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society Press|page=57}}</ref>
For most of the next century, the park was a traditional city square with a central fountain and sidewalks radiating about it. In the early 1970s, the park became known as the “Brickyard” after a renovation covered much of the square in bricks. After his death in 1974, the park was officially renamed after Norman Mears, a St. Paul inventor in the printing and etching field; his inventions were used to fight World War II and make color televisions. After retirement, Mears had set his sights on the revitalization of Lowertown.<ref name="millet"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Norman B. Mears|url=http://www.minnesotainventors.org/inductees/norman-b-mears.html|website=Minnesota Inventors Hall of Fame}}</ref>
Modern-day Mears Park was opened in 1992 following a major reconstruction designed by landscape architect Don Ganje and artist Brad Goldberg. The new design received rave reviews for brilliantly mixing natural and manmade elements, from the rocky stream to the metal bandshell, and has proven popular year after year. Today the park sits in the middle of a re-energized Lowertown, hosting handfuls of fairs and festivals throughout the season including [http://musicinmears.com/ Music in Mears] the [[Twin Cities Jazz Festival]] and [[Concrete and Grass Music Festival]]. Volunteers known as the Friends of Mears Park maintain the gardens.<ref name="millet"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lowertownlanding.com/lowertown-historic-places-mears-park|title=Mears Park |publisher=Lowertown Landing |date= |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref>
==Crane Ordway Building== Crane and Ordway manufactured valves, fittings, and supplies for steam engines.<ref>[http://saintpaulhistorical.com/items/show/217 “Crane Building,” City of Saint Paul and the Saint Paul Heritage Preservation Commission, Saint Paul Historical, 1988]</ref> Rogers and Ordway was the successor company to Wilson & Rogers, the oldest firm in the line of plumbing and steam fittings in the Northwest. At one time, The Crane Company was the largest manufacturer of valves, fittings, and steam supplies in the world, employing over 3,000 men at the factory in Chicago factory. In 1892 Crane bought out the Rugg-Fuller Company in Minneapolis.
On January 1, 1893 [[Richard T. Crane|Richard Teller Crane]] of Chicago, Illinois and [[Lucius Pond Ordway]] of St. Paul, Minnesota incorporated the '''Crane & Ordway Company'''. It consolidated the firms of Rogers and Ordway of St. Paul and Duluth with a branch of the Crane Co. in Minneapolis,<ref name=valve>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gD7OAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA313&lpg=PA313&dq=crane+ordway+building+st+paul&source=bl&ots=1TmIFbJHed&sig=UjAyjFgRK2u4Sx_1Rb7rZpCO1BI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFQQ6AEwCTgeahUKEwj8gJWEyYvGAhXBjpIKHV8sAIk#v=onepage&q=crane%20ordway%20building%20st%20paul&f=false ''The Valve World'', (Justin W. McEachren), Crane Company, 1922]</ref> uniting all the large interests in this line of business in the Northwest. Lucius Ordway, became vice president and general manager of Crane & Ordway. Ordway came to St. Paul from Providence, E. I., in 1883 and worked for Wilson & Kogers until 1886, when he became a member of the firm of Rogers & Ordway,
The company dealt in a general line of pipe, fittings, boilers, pumps, pumping machinery, and plumbers' and steam-fitters' supplies.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=NMEcAQAAMAAJ&pg=PP6&lpg=PP6&dq=crane+ordway+building+st+paul&source=bl&ots=4ns4SSWC5q&sig=htMMbGEb2eivF1UL_jZmKGg1Q6U&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAjgoahUKEwiU-YyR0ovGAhWCQpIKHQY_AKA#v=onepage&q=crane%20ordway%20building%20st%20paul&f=false ''Western Magazine'', January, 1921]</ref> It did an extensive business in well-drilling machinery, windmills, and large irrigating plant outfits of all descriptions, furnishing estimates and designs and complete plans for water works. Crane later became part of [[American Standard Brands|American Standard]]. Mr. Ordway went on to help build the [[3M]] company.
The building, completed in 1904, was designed by [[Reed and Stem]], the architectural firm that designed [[Grand Central Terminal]] in New York and the St. Paul Hotel in downtown St. Paul. It had been vacant for 30 years prior to Aeon, a non-profit developer of affordable housing, restoring it in 2006. The historic warehouse now offers 70 units of affordable rental apartments.
==Neighborhood architects== Architects who contributed to the neighborhood include [[Cass Gilbert]], [[J. Walter Stevens]], and [[Charles Sumner Frost]].{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}

revision.text:
{{For|the United States Marine Corps Reserve|Marine Forces Reserve}} {{Update|date = December 2014}} [[File:Goat Island Marine Reserve.JPG|thumb|300px|right|<center>Cape Rodney-Okakari Point, [[Goat Island (Auckland)|Goat Island]] Marine Reserve (Leigh, Warkworth, New Zealand).</center>]]
A '''marine reserve''' is a type of [[marine protected area]] that has [[legal]] protection against [[fishing]] or development. As of 2007 less than 1% of the world’s oceans had been set aside in marine reserves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eoearth.org/article/Marine_reserves|title=Marine reserves|author=Ben Halpern|publisher=}}</ref> Benefits include increases in the diversity, density, biomass, body size and reproductive potential of fishery and other species within their boundaries.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1080/08920753.2014.877758| title = Introduction| journal = Coastal Management| volume = 42| issue = 2| pages = 81–86| year = 2014| last1 = White | first1 = A. T. | last2 = Green | first2 = A. L. }}</ref>
As of 2010, scientists had studied more than 150 marine reserves in at least 61 countries and monitored biological changes inside the reserves. The number of species in each study ranged from 1 to 250 and the reserves ranged in size from 0.006 to 800 square kilometers (0.002 to 310 square miles).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.piscoweb.org/outreach/pubs/reserves|title=The Science of Marine Reserves|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030323214527/http://www.piscoweb.org/outreach/pubs/reserves/|archivedate=2003-03-23|df=}}</ref> In 2014, the World Parks Association adopted a target of establishing no-take zones for 30% of each habitat globally.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://depts.washington.edu/mpanews/MPA140.pdf|title = World Parks Congress recommends target of 30% no-take MPA coverage worldwide|last = |first = |date = December 2014|work = MPA News|access-date = January 2015}}</ref>
== Design ==
A review of studies of 34 families (210 species) of coral reef fishes demonstrates that the design of a marine reserve has important implications for its ability to protect habitat and focal species.<ref name=green1>{{cite journal |journal=Biological Reviews | year=2014 | doi=10.1111/brv.12155 | title=Larval dispersal and movement patterns of coral reef fishes, and implications for marine reserve network design | first1=Alison L. |last1=Green | first2=Aileen P. |last2=Maypa | first3=Glenn R. |last3=Almany | first4=Kevin L. |last4=Rhodes | first5=Rebecca |last5=Weeks | first6=Rene A. |last6=Abesamis | first7=Mary G. |last7=Gleason | first8=Peter J. |last8=Mumby | first9=Alan T. |last9=White | pmid=25423947 | volume=90 | pages=1215–47}}</ref>
=== Size and shape === Effective reserves included habitats that support the life history of focal species (e.g. home ranges, nursery grounds, migration corridors and spawning aggregations), and were located to accommodate movement patterns among them.<ref name="green1" />
Movement patterns (home ranges, [[ontogenetic]] shifts and spawning migrations) vary among and within species, and are influenced by factors such as size, sex, behaviour, density, habitat characteristics, season, tide and time of day. For example, damselfishes, butterflyfishes and angelfishes travel <0.1–0.5 km, while some sharks and tuna migrate over thousands of kilometres. Larval dispersal distances tend to be <5–15 km, and self-recruitment to new habitat is common.<ref name="green1"/>
The review indicated that effective marine reserves are more than twice the size of the home range of focal/target species (in all directions). The presence of effective marine management outside the reserve may allow smaller reserves.<ref name="green1" /> Reserve size recommendations apply to the specific habitats of focal species, not the overall size. For example, coral reef species require coral reef habitats rather than open ocean or seagrass beds.<ref name=":0"/>
Marine reserve whose boundaries are extensively fished benefit from compact shapes (e.g., squares or circles rather than elongated rectangles). Including whole ecological units (e.g., an offshore reef) can reduce exports where that is desired.<ref name=":0"/>

some (e.g. [[Coris aygula]]) || 5 || || || |- | || [[Humphead wrasse|Humphead]] (''Cheilinus undulatus'') || 10 || || || |}
=== Habitats === Minimum sustainable population sizes have not been determined for most marine populations. Instead, fisheries ecologists use the fraction of unfished stock levels as a proxy. Meta-analyses suggest that maintaining populations above ∼37% of those levels generally ensures stable populations, although variations in fishing pressure allow fractions as small as 10% or as large as 40% (to protect species such as sharks and some grouper that have lower reproductive output or slower maturation). Higher fractions of habitat protection may protect areas vulnerable to disturbances such as typhoons or climate change. 20–30% protection can achieve fisheries objectives in areas with controlled fishing pressure and is the minimum level of habitat protection recommended by [[IUCN]]-[[World Commission on Protected Areas|WCPA]].
=== Special areas === Many fish species congregate to facilitate spawning. Such congregations are spatially and temporally predictable and increase the species' vulnerability to overfishing. Species such as groupers and rabbitfishes travel long distances to congregate for days or weeks. Such gatherings are their only opportunities to reproduce and are crucial to population maintenance. Species such as snappers and parrotfishes congregate in feeding or resting areas. Juveniles may congregate in nursery areas without adults. Such special areas may require only seasonal protections if at other times no vital activities are taking place. Such reserves must be spaced to allow focal species to journey among them. If the location of such special areas is unknown, or is too large to include in a reserve, management approaches such as seasonal capture and sales restrictions may provide some protection. [[Sea turtle]] nesting areas, [[dugong]] feeding areas, [[cetacean]] migratory corridors and calving grounds are examples of other special areas that can be protected seasonally. Other types of special areas include isolated habitats that have unique assemblages and populations, habitats that are important for [[endemic species]] and highly diverse areas.<ref name=":0"/>
=== Isolated populations === Isolated populations (e.g.,those on remote [[atolls]]) have high conservation value where they harbor endemic species and/or unique assemblages. A location or population 20–30 km from its nearest neighbor generally qualifies as isolated in the absence of a persistent linking current. Their isolation (low connectivity) requires such areas to be largely self-replenishing. This leaves them less resilient to disturbance. Sustaining their marine species requires a higher fraction of living areas to be protected.<ref name=":0" />
=== Recovery === Coral reef fish species recovery rates (from e.g., overfishing) depend on their life history and factors such as ecological characteristics, fishing intensity and population size. In the [[Coral Triangle]], species at lower [[trophic levels]] that have smaller maximum sizes, faster growth and maturation rates and shorter life spans tend to recover more quickly than species having the opposite characteristics. For example, in the Philippines, populations of planktivores (e.g., fusiliers) and some herbivores (e.g., parrotfishes) recovered in ''<''5–10 years in marine reserves, while predators (e.g., groupers) took 20–40 years.<ref name=":0" /> Increased fishing pressure adversely affects recovery rates (e.g., Great Barrier Reef and Papua New Guinea).<ref name=":0" />
Long-term protection allows species with slower recovery rates to achieve and maintain ecosystem health and associated fishery benefits. Permanent protection protects these species over the long-term. Short-term protections do not allow slow-recovering species to reach or maintain stable populations.<ref name=":0" />
In some Coral Triangle countries (e.g., Papua New Guinea and Solomon Islands), short term protections are the most common form of traditional marine resource management. These protections can help address problems at lower trophic levels (e.g., herbivores) or allow spawning to succeed. Other reasons for adopting short-term protections include allowing communities to stockpile resources for feasts or close areas for cultural reasons. Short-term/periodic reserves also may function as partial insurance by enhancing overall ecosystem resilience against catastrophes. Reopened reserves can be protected by management controls that limit the harvest to less than the increase achieved during closure, although at greatly reduced recovery rates.<ref name=":0" />
=== Resilience === Some habitats and species are better prepared environmental changes or extremes. These include coral communities that handle high sea surface temperature (SST); areas with variable SSTs and carbonate chemistry and areas adjacent to undeveloped low-lying inland areas that coastal habitats can expand into as [[sea levels]] rise. Such areas constitute [[climate change]] refugia and can potentially better protect biodiversity than more fragile areas. They may also provide fishery benefits, since habitat loss from climate change is a major fishery threat.<ref name=":0" />
=== Local practices === Local practices such as overfishing, blast fishing, trawling, coastal development and pollution threaten many marine habitats. These threats decrease ecosystem health and productivity and adversely affect focal and other species. Such practices can also decrease resilience. Some practices that originate beyond reserve boundaries (e.g., [[Surface runoff|runoff]]) can be mitigated by considering their impacts within broader management frameworks. Areas that are not threatened by such practices and that are adjacent to other unthreatening areas may be better choices for reserves.<ref name=":0" />
== Networks == Networks of marine reserves can support both [[fisheries management]] and [[biodiversity conservation]]. The size, spacing and location of reserves within a network must respect larval dispersal and movement patterns of species that are targeted for protection.<ref name="green1" />
=== Design === Existing ecological guidelines for designing networks independently focus on achieving either fisheries, biodiversity or climate change objectives or combinations of fisheries and biodiversity or biodiversity and climate change. These three goals have different implications for network design. The most important are reserve size and protection duration (permanent, long term, short term, or periodic closures).<ref name=":0"/>
==== Diversity ==== Maintaining diversity involves protecting all species. Generally this involves protecting adequate examples of each major habitat (e.g., each type of coral reef, mangrove and seagrass community). Resiliency to threats improves when multiple examples of each habitat are protected.<ref name=":0"/>
To address biodiversity or climate change, reserves 4–20 km across are recommended, because they protect larger populations of more species.<ref name=":0" />
=== Climate change === Protecting areas that have already proven resilient to ecological changes and/or are relatively well-protected by other protocols are likely to better survive climate change as well.<ref name=":0" />
==== Fisheries ==== Reserves 0.5–1 km across export more adults and larvae to fished areas, potentially increasing recruitment and stock replenishment there. Such small reserves are common in the [[Coral Triangle]], where they benefited some fisheries.<ref name=":0"/>
=== Connectivity === Connectivity is the linking of local populations through the (voluntary) dispersal of individuals. Connected reserves are close enough to each other that larvae, juveniles or adults can cross from one to another as their behavior patterns dictate. Connectivity is a key factor in network design, since it allows a disturbed reserve to recover by recruiting individuals from other, potentially overpopulated, reserves. Effective networks spaced reserves at distances of <15 km from each other, with smaller reserves spaced more closely.<ref name="green1" />
Most coastal fish species have a bipartite life cycle where larvae are [[pelagic]] before settling out of the [[plankton]] to live on a reef. While these fish travel varying distances during their life history, their larvae have the potential to move 10s–100s of km, more than the more sedentary adults and juveniles, which have home ranges of <1 m to a few km. Adults and juveniles of some species travel 10s–100s of kilometers as they mature to reach appropriate habitats (e.g., such as coral reef, mangrove and seagrass habitats) or to migrate to spawning areas. When adults and juveniles leave a marine reserve, they become vulnerable to fishing. However, larvae can generally leave a reserve without elevated risk because of their small size and limited fishery exposure. Effective networks account for the movement patterns of target species at each life cycle stage.<ref name=":0"/>
Given a strong, consistent current, siting marine reserves upstream increases downstream populations.<ref name=":0"/>
== Other protected marine categories == Marine reserves are distinct [[marine park]]s, but there is some overlap in usage.
== Open ocean reserves == As of April 2008 no high seas marine reserves had been established. [[Greenpeace]] is campaigning for the "doughnut holes" of the western pacific to be declared as marine reserves<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.greenpeace.org/international/campaigns/oceans/marine-reserves/pacific-tuna-need-marine-reserves | title= The Pacific Commons -- first high seas marine reserve? | work= | accessdate=2008-04-27 | year=2007 | publisher=[[Greenpeace Australia Pacific]] | last= | first= | coauthors= | pages= | quote=The Western and Central Pacific Ocean is the world's largest tuna fishery. Over half of the tuna consumed worldwide is taken from this area. Rampant overfishing is destroying this fishery; relatively healthy just a few years ago. Today, two key Pacific species, Bigeye and Yellowfin could face collapse unless urgent action is taken.}}</ref> and for 40 percent of the world’s oceans to be so protected.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.greenpeace.org/international/campaigns/oceans/marine-reserves | title= Marine reserves | work= | accessdate=2008-04-27 | year=2007 | publisher=[[Greenpeace Australia Pacific]] | last= | first= | coauthors= | pages= | quote=A growing body of scientific evidence that demonstrates what we at Greenpeace have been saying for a long time: that the establishment of large-scale networks of marine reserves, urgently needed to protect marine species and their habitats, could be key to reversing global fisheries decline.}}</ref>
== By country ==
=== Australia === * [[Great Barrier Reef Marine Park]] is the largest marine park, at 350,000 km<sup>2</sup> or 217,000 miles<sup>2</sup> and is partially a marine reserve. * [[Great Australian Bight Marine Park]] * [[Shark Bay Marine Park]]
=== New Zealand === {{main|Marine reserves of New Zealand}} [[New Zealand]] has 37 marine reserves spread around the [[North Island|North]] and [[South Island|South]] Islands and other outlying islands.<ref name=SubantarcticReserves>{{cite web|title=New marine reserves set up in subantarctic|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11212495|publisher=nzherald.co.nz|accessdate=2 March 2014}}</ref> These are 'no take' areas where all forms of exploitation are prohibited. Marine reserves are administered by the [[Department of Conservation (New Zealand)|Department of Conservation]]. New Zealand's marine environment is more than 15 times larger than its terrestrial area,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/marine-and-coastal/marine-protected-areas/|title=Marine Protected Areas|publisher=}}</ref> however only 9.5% of New Zealand's [[territorial waters]] are in marine reserves, while 0.4% of New Zealand's [[exclusive economic zone]] (EEZ) is currently protected.<ref name="subAntNZherald">{{cite web|title=Marine reserves south of NZ approved by MPs|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11200857|publisher=nzherald.co.nz|accessdate=2 March 2014}}</ref>
=== British Indian Ocean Territory === * [[Chagos Marine Protected Area|Chagos Marine Reserve]] is the largest 'no take' marine reserve with more than 540,000 km<sup>2</sup> ** It is said to be one of the world's richest marine ecosystems.<ref name=Chagos>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8599125.stm|title=BBC News - UK sets up Chagos Islands marine reserve|publisher=}}</ref> ** Hosts the world's biggest living coral structure - the Great Chagos Bank.<ref name=Chagos/> ** Home to more than 220 coral species, which is almost half the recorded species of the entire Indian Ocean.<ref name=Chagos/> ** Contains more than 1,000 species of reef fish.<ref name=Chagos/>
== See also == *[[Marine park]] *[[Marine Protected Area]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * {{cite journal | last1 = Halpern | first1 = B. | last2 = Warner | first2 = R. | year = 2002 | title = Marine reserves have rapid and lasting effects | url = | journal = Ecology Letters | volume = 5 | issue = | pages = 361–366 | doi=10.1046/j.1461-0248.2002.00326.x}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Russ | first1 = G. R. | last2 = Alcala | first2 = A. C. | year = 2004 | title = Marine reserves: long-term protection is required for full recovery of predatory fish species | url = | journal = [[Oecologia]] | volume = 138 | issue = | pages = 622–627 | doi=10.1007/s00442-003-1456-4}}
== External links == {{commons category|Marine reserves}} *{{Cite web|title = Marine Reserves Factsheet|url = http://waittinstitute.org/marinereserves/|accessdate = 2015-06-08|first = |last = |publisher = Waitt Institute }} *[http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/campaigns/oceans/marine-reserves/roadmap-to-recovery/ Greenpeace is calling for a global network of Marine reserves] *[http://www.waittfoundation.org/marine-protected-areas Waitt Foundation Marine Protected Areas] *[http://www.mpatlas.org MPAtlas.org]{{Clear}} {{fishery science topics|expanded=management}}
