revision.comment: /* Secondary trends */ Fix double space in rendered output
revision.text:
A '''market trend''' is a perceived tendency of [[financial market]]s to move in a particular direction over time.<ref name="Fontanillsetal2001">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gtrLvlojNzIC&pg=PA91&dq=stock+market+trends#v=onepage&q=stock%20market%20trends&f=false |title=The Stock Market Course |author=George Fontanills, Tommy Gentile |publisher=John Wiley and Sons Inc.|page=91 |date=2001}}</ref> These trends are classified as ''secular'' for long time frames, ''primary'' for medium time frames, and ''secondary'' for short time frames.<ref name=Edwards>{{cite book|last=Edwards|first=R.|last2=McGee|first2=J.|last3=Bessetti|first3=W. H. C. |title=Technical Analysis of Stock Trends|publisher= [[CRC Press]]|year= 2007|isbn=978-0-8493-3772-7 |ref=harvnb}}</ref> Traders attempt to identify market trends using [[technical analysis]], a framework which characterizes market trends as predictable price tendencies within the market when price reaches support and resistance levels, varying over time.
A trend can only be determined in hindsight, since at any time prices in the future are not known.
==Market terminology== {{more|Bull (stock market speculator)}} The terms "bull market" and "bear market" describe upward and downward market trends, respectively,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Preis | first = Tobias | last2 = Stanley | first2 = H. Eugene | title = Bubble trouble: Can a Law Describe Bubbles and Crashes in Financial Markets? | journal = [[Physics World]] | volume = 24 | pages = 29–32 | year = 2011 | doi = }}</ref> and can be used to describe either the market as a whole or specific sectors and securities.<ref name=Edwards/> The names perhaps correspond to the fact that a [[bull]] attacks by lifting its horns upward, while a [[bear]] strikes with its claws in a downward motion.<ref name="Fontanillsetal2001"/><ref name="Investopedia">{{cite web |url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/bullmarket.asp |title=Bull Market |accessdate=2016-02-21}}</ref>
==Secular trends== A secular market trend is a long-term trend that lasts 5 to 25 years and consists of a series of primary trends. A secular bear market consists of smaller bull markets and larger bear markets; a secular bull market consists of larger bull markets and smaller bear markets.
In a secular bull market the prevailing trend is "bullish" or upward-moving. The United States stock market was described as being in a secular bull market from about 1983 to 2000 (or 2007), with brief upsets including the [[Black Monday (1987)|crash of 1987]] and the market collapse of 2000–2002 triggered by the [[dot-com bubble]].
In a secular bear market, the prevailing trend is "bearish" or downward-moving. An example of a secular bear market occurred in [[gold]] between January 1980 to June 1999, culminating with the [[Brown Bottom]]. During this period the nominal gold price fell from a high of $850/oz ($30/g) to a low of $253/oz ($9/g),<ref>[http://www.kitco.com/LFgif/au968-999.gif Chart of gold 1968–99]</ref> and became part of the [[Great Commodities Depression]].
==Primary trends== {{anchor|Primary trends}} [[File:Bulle und Bär Frankfurt.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Statues of the two symbolic beasts of finance, the bear and the bull, in front of the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]].]] A primary trend has broad support throughout the entire market (most [[Sector (economic)|sectors]]) and lasts for a year or more. ===Bull market===<!-- This section is linked from [[Bull]] --> [[File:Wall Street bubbles - Always the same - Keppler 1901.jpg|thumb|right|A 1901 cartoon depicting financier [[J. P. Morgan]] as a bull with eager investors]] A bull market is a period of generally rising prices. The start of a bull market is marked by widespread pessimism. This point is when the "crowd" is the most "bearish".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=MW_FmuvcneEC&pg=PT222&lpg=PT222#v=onepage&q&f=false Winning on Wall Street] Martin Zweig</ref> The feeling of despondency changes to hope, "optimism", and eventually euphoria, as the bull runs its course.<ref>[http://www.minyanville.com/business-news/markets/articles/The-6-Stages-of-Bull-Markets/4/1/2013/id/48996 The 6 Stages Of Bull Markets -- And Where We Are Right Now | Markets | Minyanville's Wall Street] [[Minyanville]]</ref> This often leads the economic cycle, for example in a full [[recession]], or earlier.
An analysis of [[Morningstar, Inc.]] stock market data from 1926 to 2014 found that a typical bull market "lasted 8.5 years with an average cumulative total return of 458%", while annualized gains for bull markets range from 14.9% to 34.1%.<ref>"[http://www.feltzwealthplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/compliance-Bull-and-Bear-Markets-chart-Oct-2014.pdf History of U.S. Bear and Bull Markets Since 1926] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509115004/http://www.feltzwealthplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/compliance-Bull-and-Bear-Markets-chart-Oct-2014.pdf |date=2016-05-09 }}", chart by First Trust Portfolios L.P., accessed 01 May 2016</ref>
====Examples==== :India's [[Bombay Stock Exchange]] Index, [[BSE SENSEX]], had a major bull market trend for about five years from April 2003 to January 2008 as it increased from 2,900 points to 21,000 points, more than a 6-fold rise in 5 years. :Notable bull markets marked the 1925–1929, 1953–1957 and the 1993–1997 periods when the U.S. and many other stock markets rose; while the first period ended abruptly with the start of the [[Great Depression]], the end of the later time periods were mostly periods of [[Soft landing (economics)|soft landing]], which became large bear markets. (see: [[Recession of 1960–61]] and the [[dot-com bubble]] in 2000–2001)
===Bear market=== A bear market is a general decline in the stock market over a period of time.<ref>{{cite book | last = O'Sullivan | first = Arthur |author2=Steven M. Sheffrin | title = Economics: Principles in Action | publisher = Pearson Prentice Hall | year = 2003 | page = 290 | isbn = 0-13-063085-3}}</ref> It is a transition from high investor optimism to widespread investor fear and pessimism. According to [[The Vanguard Group]], "While there's no agreed-upon definition of a bear market, one generally accepted measure is a price decline of 20% or more over at least a two-month period."<ref>"[https://retirementplans.vanguard.com/VGApp/pe/PubVgiNews?ArticleName=Stayingcalmbearmkt Staying calm during a bear market] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717184619/https://retirementplans.vanguard.com/VGApp/pe/PubVgiNews?ArticleName=Stayingcalmbearmkt |date=2011-07-17 }}". Vanguard Group.</ref>
A smaller decline of 10 to 20% is considered a correction. Once a market enters correction or bear market territory, it isn't considered to have exited that territory until a new high is reached.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/stop-saying-the-dow-is-moving-in-and-out-of-correction-that-is-not-how-stock-market-moves-work-2018-03-23|title=Stop saying the Dow is moving in and out of correction! That is not how stock-market moves work|publisher=MarketWatch|author=Mark DeCambre|date=April 6, 2018|accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
An analysis of [[Morningstar, Inc.]] stock market data from 1926 to 2014 found that a typical bear market "lasted 1.3 years with an average cumulative loss of −41%", while annualized declines for bear markets range from −19.7% to −47%.<ref>"[http://www.feltzwealthplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/compliance-Bull-and-Bear-Markets-chart-Oct-2014.pdf History of U.S. Bear and Bull Markets Since 1926] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509115004/http://www.feltzwealthplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/compliance-Bull-and-Bear-Markets-chart-Oct-2014.pdf |date=2016-05-09 }}", chart by First Trust Portfolios L.P., accessed 01 May 2016</ref>
====Examples==== :A bear market followed the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]] and erased 89% (from 386 to 40) of the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]]'s market capitalization by July 1932, marking the start of the [[Great Depression]]. After regaining nearly 50% of its losses, a longer bear market from 1937 to 1942 occurred in which the market was again cut in half. Another long-term bear market occurred from about 1973 to 1982, encompassing the [[1970s energy crisis]] and the high unemployment of the early 1980s. Yet another bear market occurred between March 2000 and October 2002. Recent examples occurred between October 2007 and March 2009, as a result of the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]]. See also [[2015 Chinese stock market crash]].
===Market top=== A market top (or market high) is usually not a dramatic event. The market has simply reached the highest point that it will, for some time (usually a few years). It is retroactively defined as market participants are not aware of it as it happens. A decline then follows, usually gradually at first and later with more rapidity. William J. O'Neil and company report that since the 1950s a market top is characterized by three to five distribution days in a major market index occurring within a relatively short period of time. Distribution is a decline in price with higher volume than the preceding session.
====Examples==== :The peak of the [[dot-com bubble]] (as measured by the [[NASDAQ-100]]) occurred on March 24, 2000. The index closed at 4,704.73. The Nasdaq peaked at 5,132.50 and the S&P 500 at 1525.20.
A recent peak for the broad U.S. market was October 9, 2007. The [[S&P 500]] index closed at 1,565 and the Nasdaq at 2861.50.
===Market bottom=== A market bottom is a trend reversal, the end of a market downturn, and the beginning of an upward moving trend (bull market).
It is very difficult to identify a bottom (referred to by investors as "bottom picking") while it is occurring. The upturn following a decline is often short-lived and prices might resume their decline. This would bring a loss for the investor who purchased stock(s) during a misperceived or "false" market bottom.
[[Baron Rothschild]] is said to have advised that the best time to buy is when there is "blood in the streets", i.e., when the markets have fallen drastically and investor sentiment is extremely negative.<ref>[http://www.fool.com/investing/small-cap/2007/05/02/buy-when-theres-blood-in-the-streets.aspx Buy When There's Blood in the Streets]</ref>
====Examples==== :Some examples of market bottoms, in terms of the closing values of the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] (DJIA) include: :*The Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a bottom at 1738.74 on 19 October 1987, as a result of the decline from 2722.41 on 25 August 1987. This day was called Black Monday (chart<ref>[http://stockcharts.com/h-sc/ui?s=$INDU&p=D&st=1987-08-01&en=1987-12-31&id=p95907824619 stockcharts.com chart]</ref>). :* A bottom of 7286.27 was reached on the DJIA on 9 October 2002 as a result of the decline from 11722.98 on 14 January 2000. This included an intermediate bottom of 8235.81 on 21 September 2001 (a 14% change from 10 September) which led to an intermediate top of 10635.25 on 19 March 2002 (chart<ref>[http://stockcharts.com/h-sc/ui?s=$INDU&p=D&st=2000-01-01&en=2002-12-31&id=p94927308656 stockcharts.com chart]</ref>). The "tech-heavy" Nasdaq fell a more precipitous 79% from its 5132 peak (10 March 2000) to its 1108 bottom (10 October 2002).
:*A bottom of 6,440.08 (DJIA) on 9 March 2009 was reached after a decline associated with the [[subprime mortgage crisis]] starting at 14164.41 on 9 October 2007 (chart<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stockcharts.com/h-sc/ui?s=$INDU&p=D&st=2007-06-01&en=2009-05-17&id=p70946023540 |title=$INDU - SharpCharts Workbench |publisher=StockCharts.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref>).
==Secondary trends== Secondary trends are short-term changes in price direction within a primary trend. They may last for a few weeks or a few months.
One type of secondary market trend is called a market '''correction'''. A correction is a short-term price decline of 5% to 20% or so.<ref>Technical Analysis of Stock Trends, Robert D. Edwards and John Magee p. 479.</ref> An example occurred from April to June 2010, when the [[S&P 500]] went from above 1200 to near 1000; this was hailed{{by whom?|date=June 2018}} as the end of the bull market and start of a bear market, but it was not, and the market turned back up. A correction is a downward movement that is not large enough to be a bear market (ex post).
Another type of secondary trend is called a '''bear [[Rally (stock market)|market rally]]''' (sometimes called "sucker's rally" or "[[dead cat bounce]]") which consists of a market-price increase of only 10% or 20% before the prevailing, bear-market trend resumes.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/bear-market-rally.asp|title= Bear Market Rally Definition|publisher= Investopedia}}</ref> Bear market rallies occurred in the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average |Dow Jones]] index after the 1929 stock market crash, leading down to the market bottom in 1932, and throughout the late 1960s and early 1970s. The [[Japan]]ese [[Nikkei 225]] has tracked a number of bear-market rallies since the late 1980s while experiencing an overall long-term downward trend.
Malcolm Maiden characterized the Australian market {{as of|2015|January}} as a "[[meerkat]] market", being timid with low [[consumer sentiment | consumer-]] and [[business sentiment | business-sentiment]].<ref> {{cite news |last1= Maiden|first1= Malcolm |title= Australia is in a meerkat market as animal spirits remain wary |url= http://www.canberratimes.com.au/business/comment-and-analysis/australia-is-in-a-meerkat-market-as-animal-spirits-remain-wary-20150102-12ghrg.html |accessdate= 4 January 2015|work= The Canberra Times |publisher= Fairfax Media|date= 2 January 2015 | quote = Animal spirits are Australia's missing link as the new year begins. They are there, but they are timid: you might call this a meerkat market. }} </ref>
==Causes==
The price of assets such as stocks is set by supply and demand. By definition, the market balances buyers and sellers, so it's impossible to literally have 'more buyers than sellers' or vice versa, although that is a common expression. For a surge in demand, the buyers will increase the price they are willing to pay, while the sellers will increase the price they wish to receive. For a surge in supply, the opposite happens.
Supply and demand are created when investors shift allocation of investment between asset types. For example, at one time, investors may move money from government bonds to "tech" stocks; at another time, they may move money from "tech" stocks to government bonds. In each case, this will affect the price of both types of assets.
Generally, investors try to follow a [[Market timing|buy-low, sell-high]] strategy but often mistakenly end up buying high and selling low.<ref>[http://news.morningstar.com/articlenet/article.aspx?id=325664 Bad Timing Eats Away at Investor Returns]</ref> Contrarian investors and traders attempt to "fade" the investors' actions (buy when they are selling, sell when they are buying). A time when most investors are selling stocks is known as distribution, while a time when most investors are buying stocks is known as accumulation.
According to standard theory, a decrease in price will result in less supply and more demand, while an increase in price will do the opposite. This works well for most assets but it often works in reverse for stocks due to the mistake many investors make of buying high in a state of euphoria and selling low in a state of fear or panic as a result of the herding instinct. In case an increase in price causes an increase in demand, or a decrease in price causes an increase in supply, this destroys the expected negative feedback loop and prices will be unstable.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilcox|first1=Jarrod W.|last2=Fabozzi|first2=Frank J.|title=Financial Advice and Investment Decisions: A Manifesto for Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mnEnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT58#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> This can be seen in a bubble or crash.
==Investor sentiment== Investor sentiment is a [[contrarian]] stock market indicator.
When a high proportion of investors express a bearish (negative) sentiment, some analysts consider it to be a strong signal that a market bottom may be near. The predictive capability of such a signal (see also [[market sentiment]]) is thought to be highest when investor sentiment reaches extreme values.<ref>Trying to Plumb a Bottom, By MARK HULBERT, http://online.barrons.com/article/SB122652105098621685.html</ref> Indicators that measure investor sentiment may include:{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}
[[David Hirshleifer]] sees in the trend phenomenon a path starting with underreaction and ending in overreaction by investors / traders.
*Investor Intelligence Sentiment Index: If the Bull-Bear spread (% of Bulls − % of Bears) is close to a historic low, it may signal a bottom. Typically, the number of bears surveyed would exceed the number of bulls. However, if the number of bulls is at an extreme high and the number of bears is at an extreme low, historically, a market top may have occurred or is close to occurring. This contrarian measure is more reliable for its coincidental timing at market lows than tops. *[[American Association of Individual Investors]] (AAII) sentiment indicator: Many feel that the majority of the decline has already occurred once this indicator gives a reading of minus 15% or below. *Other sentiment indicators include the Nova-Ursa ratio, the Short Interest/Total Market Float, and the [[put/call ratio]].
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Mr. Market]] * [[Black Monday (1987)|Black Monday]] * [[Bull-bear line]] * [[Business cycle]] * [[Don't fight the tape]] * [[Trend following]] * [[Recession]] * [[Economic expansion]] * [[Market sentiment]] * [[Animal spirits (Keynes)|Animal spirits]] * [[Herd mentality]] * [[Real estate trends]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/trendanalysis.asp Market trend definition, explanations, and examples provided in simple terms] * [http://www.wallstreetcourier.com/v/ti-overview.htm Description and Charts of Trend Indicators]

'''Michel Christian Bergerac''' (13 February 1932 - 11 September 2016) was a French businessman who was president of cosmetics company [[Revlon]] in succession to [[Charles Revson]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Stephen Miller obitsman |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-14/michel-bergerac-who-lost-revlon-to-ron-perelman-bid-dies-at-84 |title=Michel Bergerac, Who Fought Perelman Over Revlon, Dies at 84 |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2016-09-14 |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=By MICHAEL CORKERYSEPT. 18, 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/19/business/michel-c-bergerac-who-made-over-revlon-dies-at-84.html |title=Michel C. Bergerac, Who Made Over Revlon, Dies at 84 - The New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=2016-09-18 |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Miller |first=Stephen |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/michel-bergerac-who-diversified-revlon-before-hostile-takeover-dies-at-84/2016/09/14/768f2af0-7a90-11e6-ac8e-cf8e0dd91dc7_story.html |title=Michel Bergerac, who diversified Revlon before hostile takeover, dies at 84 |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hbs.edu/leadership/20th-century-leaders/Pages/details.aspx?profile=michel_c_bergerac |title=Michel C. Bergerac - Leadership - Harvard Business School |publisher=Hbs.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hagerty |first=James R. |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/michel-bergeracs-pay-as-revlon-executive-raised-eyebrows-in-1970s-1474047019 |title=Michel Bergerac’s Pay as Revlon Executive Raised Eyebrows in 1970s |publisher=WSJ |date=2016-09-16 |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/michel-bergerac-qcs8mjg69 |title=Michel Bergerac | Register | The Times & The Sunday Times |publisher=Thetimes.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Christopher P. Andersen |url=http://people.com/archive/michel-bergerac-a-1-5-million-dollar-man-takes-charge-at-revlon-vol-4-no-23/ |title=Michel Bergerac: a 1.5 Million Dollar Man Takes Charge at Revlon |publisher=People.com |date=1975-12-08 |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Jacques Bergerac]]

revision.text:
'''Miko Rwayitare''' (December 2, 1942 – September 25, 2007) was a Rwandan-born billionaire and the supposed father of [[mobile telecommunications]] in [[Africa]].
It is reported that he made the first [[cellular phone]] call on the African continent in 1986.[http://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/index.php?i=1301&a=1232 Rwandans mourn Miko Rwayitare] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213212804/http://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/index.php?i=1301&a=1232 |date=2013-12-13 }}, The New Times, by Edwin Musoni, September 28, 2007. He founded [[Telecel International]], an African telecommunications company.[http://www.africanleadershipacademy.org/news/celebrating-africa%E2%80%99s-unsung-heroes-miko-rwayitare Celebrating Africa’s Unsung Heroes: Miko Rwayitare] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212154501/http://www.africanleadershipacademy.org/news/celebrating-africa%E2%80%99s-unsung-heroes-miko-rwayitare |date=2013-12-12 }}, African Leadership Academy. Rwayitare was born in [[Rwanda]] and educated in [[Zaire]] (now the Democratic Republic of the Congo) at the [[Collège Saint-Esprit]] and then [[Collège Notre-Dame (Bukavu)|Collège Notre-Dame]] in [[Bukavu]] and received an engineering degree in [[Germany]] at [[University of Karlsruhe]] in 1970.
In 1996, he moved to [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]]. He lived in one of the city’s most expensive mansions on Sandhurst’s Oxford Avenue.[http://www.timeslive.co.za/business/2010/11/07/cosy-home-for-the-very-rich Cosy home for the very rich], Times Live, by Simphiwe Piliso, 07 November, 2010 .
In 2001, he purchased the Mont Rochelle winery making it the first black-owned wine estate in South Africa.[http://www.africanleadershipacademy.org/news/celebrating-africa%E2%80%99s-unsung-heroes-miko-rwayitare Celebrating Africa’s Unsung Heroes: Miko Rwayitare] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212154501/http://www.africanleadershipacademy.org/news/celebrating-africa%E2%80%99s-unsung-heroes-miko-rwayitare |date=2013-12-12 }}, African Leadership Academy. He was also the owner of [[Hôtel des Mille Collines]] on which the Film [[Hotel Rwanda]] was based.[[Hôtel des Mille Collines]] He was first married to Josephine Diur and had five children with her then married Consolatta Rwayitare and had two children. ==External links== * http://www.telecel.co.zw/ ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Rwayitare, Miko}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Rwandan businesspeople]]

{{Infobox company | name = MINDBODY Inc | native_name = | native_name_lang = | romanized_name = | trading_name = MINDBODY | logo = Mindbody-logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = MINDBODY Headquarters San Luis Obispo.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Headquarters | type = [[Public]] | traded_as = {{NASDAQ|MB}} (Class A)
[[Russell 2000 Index|Russell 2000 Component]] | ISIN = | founded = 2001 | founder = Rick Stollmeyer
Blake Beltram | fate = | hq_location = 4051 Broad Street | hq_location_city = San Luis Obispo, California | hq_location_country = United States | num_locations = | num_locations_year = | area_served = | key_people = Rick Stollmeyer (CEO) | industry = Technology | genre = | products = {{Unbulleted list|MINDBODY for Business|MINDBODY App|MINDBODY for Corporate Wellness}} | brands = | production = | services = | revenue = {{Unbulleted list|class=nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 139,021,000 (2016)|{{increase}} US$ 101,369,000 (2015)}}{{cite web|title=MB Income Statement|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1458962/000145896217000005/mb_12-31x2016x10xk.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]]|accessdate=6 February 2018}} | revenue_year = FY 2016 | operating_income = {{Unbulleted list|class=nowrap|{{increase}} US$ (21,332,000) (2016)|{{increase}} US$ (34,742,000) (2015)}} | income_year = FY 2016 | net_income = | net_income_year = {{Unbulleted list|class=nowrap|{{increase}} US$ (22,979,000) (2016)|{{increase}} US$ (36,088,000) (2015)}} | assets = {{Unbulleted list|class=nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 143,946 (2016)|{{increase}} US$ 141,414 (2015)}} | assets_year = FY 2016 | equity = {{Unbulleted list|class=nowrap|{{decrease}} US$ 101,656,000 (2016)|{{increase}} US$ 105,783,000 (2015)}} | equity_year = FY 2016 | num_employees = 1,350 | num_employees_year = 31 December 2016 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | website = {{URL|mindbodyonline.com}} | footnotes = | former_name = | coordinates = | caption = Leveraging technology to improve the wellness of the world. }} '''MINDBODY Inc''' {{NASDAQ|MB}} was founded in 2001.{{cite web|title=Tech Approach to Wellness {{!}} The East Hampton Star|url=http://easthamptonstar.com/Business/2013612/Tech-Approach-Wellness|website=easthamptonstar.com|accessdate=10 September 2016}} It provides cloud-based business management software for the wellness services industry. MINDBODY serves about 35 million consumers located in over 130 countries and territories. It provides business management software and online scheduling platforms for over 58,000 health and wellness businesses globally.{{cite web|title=Exhibit|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1458962/000162828016020301/mbq316epr.htm|website=www.sec.gov|accessdate=1 November 2016}} The company's clients include [[Bikram Yoga]] and [[Racquet and Tennis Club|New York Health & Racquet Club]].{{cite web|last1=Roof|first1=Katie|title=Mindbody IPO is the 'Uber of Wellness' {{!}} Fox Business|url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2015/06/19/mindbody-ipo-is-uber-wellness.html|publisher=FOXBusiness|accessdate=10 September 2016|date=19 June 2015}} [[ClassPass]] is one of MINDBODY's technology partners using MINDBODY's API to power the inventory on the ClassPass app.{{cite web|title=ClassPass - Work out at the best studios in your city|url=https://classpass.com/partners|website=ClassPass|accessdate=18 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=My Fitness Pal now lets you book workout classes directly from the app|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/my-fitness-pal-app-book-workout-classes-2016-10|website=Business Insider|accessdate=18 October 2016}} According to Institutional Venture Partners, ''MINDBODY is the largest global provider of online business management software to the beauty, health and wellness industry.''{{cite web|title=Global Software Provider MINDBODY Raises $35 Million – IVP|url=https://www.ivp.com/news/press-release/global-software-provider-mindbody-raises-35-million/|website=www.ivp.com|accessdate=11 September 2016}} ==History== MINDBODY was originally known as HardBody software. The latter was co-founded by Blake Beltram, Rick Stollmeyer and Robert Murphy in 2000. The company was later incorporated as MINDBODY in 2001.{{cite web|title=The culture of MindBody|url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/business/article39443244.html|publisher=The Tribune|accessdate=11 September 2016}} In 2005, MINDBODY Online was launched and it later received its first private funding round of $1 million in November 2005 from [[Tech Coast Angels]] and Pasadena Angels.{{cite web|title=Tech Coast Angels Funds 100th Company, Significant Increase in Investments in 2005; TCA Members Invest $10.7M, Venture Capital and Outside Investors Put $84.3M in TCA Portfolio Companies {{!}} Business Wire|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20051130005204/en/Tech-Coast-Angels-Funds-100th-Company-Significant|website=www.businesswire.com|accessdate=11 September 2016}} The company's first round of institutional investment came up in April 2009 to the sum of $5.6 million from Catalyst Investors.{{cite web|title=Pasadena Angels, Inc. MINDBODY Secures Funding for Business Expansion|url=http://pasadenaangels.com/2009/04/mindbody-secures-funding-for-business-expansion/|website=pasadenaangels.com|accessdate=11 September 2016}} The company received more investment in August 2010 to the sum of $14 million from [[Bessemer Venture Partners]] and Catalyst Investors with an initial portion of $11 million while the remaining $3 million was to be exercised at any time within 36 months.{{cite web|title=MindBody Raises $11M|url=http://www.finsmes.com/2010/08/mindbody-raises-11m.html|publisher=FinSMEs Ltd|accessdate=11 September 2016|date=23 August 2010}} It received another round of funding in November 2012 of $35 million from [[Bessemer Venture Partners]], [[Institutional Venture Partners]], and Catalyst Investors.{{cite web|last1=Farr|first1=Christina|title=MindBody, a Salesforce for health and beauty, abs $35M|url=https://venturebeat.com/2012/11/01/mindbody-funding/|publisher=VentureBeat|accessdate=11 September 2016}} According to Rick Stollmeyer the CEO, the funds from that round would enable the company to expand globally to link the 2 million beauty and wellness businesses operating worldwide with the hundreds of millions of consumers who can use their services. In February 2014, MINDBODY received its final round of private funding in the amount of $50 million from Bessemer Venture Partners, Institutional Venture Partners, Catalyst Investors, W Capital Partners and Montreux Equity Partners.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/business/article39468876.html|title=Mindbody raises $50 million from investors to fund growth|newspaper=sanluisobispo|access-date=2017-01-04}} In February 2015, MINDBODY acquired Fitness Mobile Apps for an undisclosed amount. At the time of the acquisition the company was creating customizable applications for iPhone, iPad, and Android platforms.{{cite web|title=MINDBODY Expands Consumer Platform with Acquisition|url=https://www.mindbodyonline.com/sites/default/files/mindbody-press_release-02_17_15-mindbody_acquires_fitness_mobile_apps.pdf|accessdate=11 September 2016}} MINDBODY went public in June 2015 raising $100M USD in capital.{{cite web|title=Mindbody (MB) Goes Public, Stock Closes Below IPO Price - Stocks in the News|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/article/mindbody-mb-goes-public-stock-closes-below-ipo-price-stocks-in-the-news-cm488973|accessdate=10 September 2016|date=19 June 2015}} In October 2015, MINDBODY integrated its MINDBODY Connect app with Fitbit, making it possible for app users to connect their Fitbit activity trackers to view personal activity data achieved during workouts scheduled at MINDBODY businesses.{{cite web|last1=Desk|first1=BWW News|title=Fitbit Adds Genuine Thermos Brand to its Roster|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwfitness/article/Fitbit-Adds-Genuine-Thermos-Brand-to-its-Roster-20151021|accessdate=1 November 2016}}{{cite web|title=The App|url=https://www.mindbodyonline.com/get-the-app|website=MINDBODY|accessdate=1 November 2016|date=25 November 2015}} In September 2016, MINDBODY acquired HealCode, a technology company that designed web tools for the fitness and wellness industry.{{cite web|title=MindBody buys Austin startup HealCode for undisclosed amount - Austin Business Journal|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/austin/news/2016/09/07/publicly-traded-wellness-company-scoops-up-austin.html|website=Austin Business Journal|accessdate=1 November 2016}} In October 2016, MINDBODY integrated with Under Armour’s [[MyFitnessPal]] app to make it possible for app users to find and book fitness classes throughout the United States directly through MyFitnessPal.{{cite web|last1=McNew|first1=Bradley Seth|title=Under Armour's New Fitness App Feature and the Importance of Digital -|url=http://www.fool.com/investing/2016/10/06/under-armours-new-mindbody-partnership.aspx?source=iaasitlnk0000003|website=The Motley Fool|accessdate=1 November 2016|date=1 November 2016}} ==Awards and recognition== * 2016 Webby Award and Webby People's Voice Award in the Mobile App: Fitness and Recreation category.{{cite web|title=MINDBODY App {{!}} The Webby Awards|url=http://webbyawards.com/winners/2016/mobile-sites-apps/general-sites-apps/fitness-recreation/mindbody-app/|publisher=[[Webby Award]]|accessdate=11 September 2016}} * MINDBODY Connect – [[Software and Information Industry Association#CODiE Awards|Codie Award]] for Best Consumer Application 2015.{{cite web|title=Winners - 2015 SIIA CODiE Awards|url=http://www.siia.net/archive/codies/2015/winners_detail.asp?nID=240|website=www.siia.net|publisher=Codie award |accessdate=11 September 2016}} * MINDBODY Express – Silicon Valley Business App: Best Finance & Management App 2015.{{cite web|title=2015 Winners|url=http://www.svbaawards.com/2015-winners.html|website=Silicon Valley Business App Awards|accessdate=1 November 2016}} * Named among the top 50 best places to work for by Glassdoor in 2016, 2015 and 2014.{{cite web|title=Glassdoor - Best Places to Work|url=https://www.glassdoor.com/Award/Best-Places-to-Work-LST_KQ0,19.htm|website=Glassdoor|accessdate=8 November 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Ames|first1=Danielle|title=Mindbody again named among 50 Best Places to Work|url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/business/article49698160.html|accessdate=11 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Sahadi|first1=Jeanne|title=Glassdoor best places to work: 50 companies that employees love|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/12/09/pf/employees-love-working-at-these-companies/|website=CNNMoney|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=11 September 2016|date=9 December 2015}} * Named among Inc. Magazine’s fastest growing companies in the U.S. (Inc 5000) annually 2008-2015, making the Inc 500 list in 2009.{{cite web|title=Find out why MindBody made Inc.'s Founders 40 List.|url=http://www.inc.com/profile/mindbody|website=Inc.com|accessdate=1 November 2016}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:2001 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Companies established in 2001]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 2001]] [[Category:Companies listed on NASDAQ]] [[Category:Cloud applications]] [[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Cloud computing providers]] [[Category:Software companies based in California]] [[Category:Internet companies of the United States]] [[Category:Business services companies established in 2001]]

revision.comment: /* Introduction */ Adding/removing wikilink(s)
revision.text:
'''Pakathon''' is a [[Boston]]-based,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shoaib|first1=Mariam|title=Pakathon - A Call To Action|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1045114|accessdate=5 April 2016|agency=Dawn News|publisher=Dawn.com|date=September 24, 2013}}</ref> registered global non-profit organization with eight global chapters in four countries: Pakistan, the United States, Canada, and Australia. Founded in 2013, Pakathon aims to create jobs through innovation and entrepreneurship<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/malik-siraj-akbar/pakathon-searching-soluti_b_8248982.html|title=Pakathon: Searching for Solutions Through Business and Technology|last=Akbar|first=Malik Siraj|date=October 6, 2015|work=|access-date=April 5, 2016|via=Huffington Post}}</ref> by mobilizing the [[Pakistani diaspora]]. By working to foster a global network of like-minded individuals, investors and entrepreneurs, Pakathon aims to solve problems in sectors such as education, healthcare, gender equality, energy and law.
== Introduction == The organization's flagship event is a weekend-long [[hackathon]] hosted in chapter cities where students and professionals develop and pitch their projects to a panel of mentors. Top-performing teams are then invited to present their ideas to a global audience where they compete for funding, mentorship, and additional support, with the aim of advancing their ideas from conception to reality. Two winning teams are then selected: one from Pakistan and another from the international host cities.
In 2015, Pakathon partnered with the [[Higher Education Commission of Pakistan]] to expand Pakathon's innovation-centred programming in up to 50 Pakistani universities.
== Impact == Pakathon's first winning team conceived the idea for ProCheck, a serialization system for authentic medicines in Pakistan. ProCheck allows customers and patients to verify authentic medicines using their mobile phones via text messaging. In November, 2015 ProCheck partnered with Ferozsons Labs, a leading manufacturer of pharmaceuticals in Pakistan, to serialize 35 million units of medicine using ProCheck's track and trace solution. As a result, more than 50,000 patients across the country will be able to distinguish between genuine and counterfeit medicines.
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Technology organizations]] [[Category:Entrepreneurship organizations]] [[Category:Pakistani diaspora]] [[Category:Organizations based in Boston]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2013]] [[Category:2013 establishments in Massachusetts]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Patrice Baldwin | image = Patrice_Baldwin_portrate.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Birth-date and age|df=yes|Month DD, YYYY}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = Drama education | occupation = }}
'''Patrice Baldwin''' was President of the [[International Drama and Theatre Education Association]] (IDEA) from 2010–13. She is Chair of National Drama, the leading subject association for UK drama and theatre educators, and National Director of [[D4LC]] (Drama for Learning and Creativity).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationaldrama.co.uk/index.php?content=nd_event&event_id=28|title=National Drama {{!}} One Forum, many voices.|last=|first=|date=2016-03-03|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303180604/http://www.nationaldrama.org.uk/|archive-date=2016-03-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref>
== Overview == Patrice Baldwin is a leading figure in the world of 'Drama for Learning'. She was Chair of National Drama (the leading association of drama and theatre educators) for more than a decade (until November 2014) and was President of the International Drama Theatre and Education Association (IDEA) from 2010 – 2013. She has also been an Executive Council Member of the World Alliance for Arts Education (WAAE). From April 2000 to June 2011 she was the local authority arts adviser for [[Norfolk County Council]] Children's Services but decided to go freelance in June 2011. This enabled her to devote more time to travelling and working abroad, as well as to developing 'Drama for Learning' in the UK. Follow her extensive education work, publications and travels by visiting her Drama Blog [http://www.patricebaldwin.me] and her professional website [http://www.patricebaldwin.net] You can also join the D4LC Facebook group she set up, to keep in contact with thousands of drama educators worldwide.<ref>[http://www.facebook.com/#!/groups/233552658275/?fref=ts]</ref>
Patrice was a primary school headteacher for eleven years and still works in schools on a consultancy basis for drama for learning, improving teaching, cultural and creative learning and primary curriculum development. She was an [[Ofsted]] inspector and a School Improvement Partner. For several years she worked as a BBC series consultant and scriptwriter for ''Let's Make a Story'' and also wrote scripts for ''First Steps in Drama'' and stories and dramatisations for ''Together'', a BBC radio assembly programme for primary schools.
Patrice Baldwin has written many articles and books for teachers, on the use of drama for learning across the curriculum and has a particular interest in links between drama, learning through imagining and neuroscience, She is also known for her work on improving literacy through Drama. She is author of 'Stimulating Drama', ''The Drama Box'', 'The Drama Book', 'Teaching Literacy Through Drama – creative approaches'<ref>http://www.wwwords.co.uk/pdf/viewpdf.asp?j=forum&vol=44&issue=3&year=2002&article=Forum_44-3_CoreContent&id=70.15.67.69</ref> and ''With Drama in Mind – real learning in imagined worlds'' and The Primary Drama Handbook' and 'School Improvement Through Drama'.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.continuumbooks.com/books/detail.aspx?BookId=132050 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406132940/http://www.continuumbooks.com/books/detail.aspx?BookId=132050 |archivedate=6 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}"</ref> In May 2012 her second edition of 'With Drama in Mind' was published by Continuum/Bloomsbury and in October 2012 her book, 'Inspiring Writing Through Drama' (co-written with Rob John), was also published by Bloomsbury.
Patrice Baldwin created 'Drama for Learning and Creativity' (D4LC), a national school improvement initiative that was piloted in Norfolk in 2005 and was supported by the [[Qualifications and Curriculum Authority]], [[Creative Partnerships]] and the [[National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts]] as well as [[Norfolk County Council]]. D4LC later became an IDEA project and spread internationally. She presented it at UNESCO's 2nd International Arts Education Conferences in South Korea and also, in Taiwan and Newcastle at World Creativity Summits. D4LC is an initiative that links visiting drama specialists with pairs of non-specialist drama teachers in schools. Together they work in partnership to use drama as a way of learning and teaching. They evaluate and share the impact. More than 280 schools in Norfolk became 'D4LC schools' from 2005 – 2010 and other parts of the UK (Newport in Wales and Dorset) have also set up D4LC based initiatives. D4LC was also started in Iceland under the name, 'FLISS' and has also proved successful with UK museum educators who want to extend the use of drama for learning in museums.
Patrice is a well established national and international drama workshop leader and conference keynote speaker on drama, education, arts and Creativity.<ref>http://www.alite.co.uk/newsletters/2004/february.htm</ref> In April 2011 she became freelance, in order to focus more freely on her international work. Patrice has presented at Conferences in Greece, Turkey, Iceland, Germany, Austria, Poland, Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, Australia, the Philippines, France, Norway, Sweden, Finland, New Zealand, Singapore, US and Canada, Argentina and Uruguay. She was a speaker at the 2008 and 2009 World Creativity Summits in Taiwan and Newcastle and keynote speaker at Drama Australia's 2011 Conference in Perth. She presented in June 2011 at the first Drama in Education Conference in Singapore and in 2012/13 at many Conferences, including in New Hampshire (January 2012), New Zealand (April 2012), Turkey (May and November 2012), France (May 2012), Iceland (August 2012), Canada (October 2012), Greece (November 2012), Sweden (January and May 2013), Hong Kong and Singapore (February 2013), Australia (March 2013) and France (July 2013). During 2013 she became the Cultural Leader in Theatre and Performing Arts, for Brock University, Canada.
In 2009 she was a member of Sir Jim Rose's Editorial Expert group drafting a new primary National Curriculum for England. This curriculum did not get through Parliament before the June 2010 General Election. She is now working in partnership with specialist drama teaching schools in the UK, as well as doing some visiting fellow work at various Universities and working as an Artsmark Trainer and validator for Arts Council England.
Patrice has also set up a CPD service for Norfolk schools and provides courses for a range of curriculum areas. See her website for more details. www.patricebaldwin.com
== Books == Stimulating Drama – out of print
The Drama Box and The Drama Book – out of print
Teaching Literacy Through Drama: Creative Approaches (co-written with Kate Fleming) * [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Teaching-Literacy-Through-Drama-Approaches/dp/0415255783]
With Drama in Mind: Real Learning in Imagined Worlds * [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Drama-Mind-Learning-Imagined-Worlds/dp/0826445888/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1325456464&sr=1-2]
With Drama in Mind: Real Learning in Imagined Worlds (second edition) * [http://www.continuumbooks.com/books/detail.aspx?BookId=159287&SearchType=Basic]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
The Primary Drama Handbook * [https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=the+primary+drama+handbook]

Inspiring Writing Through Drama (co-written with Rob John) * [http://www.continuumbooks.com/books/detail.aspx?BookId=159775&SubjectId=940&Subject2Id=1424]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}

revision.text:
{{For|the former [[mayor]] of [[Laredo, Texas]]|Raul G. Salinas}}
'''Raúl Salinas de Gortari''' (born August 24, 1946<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ortiz Pinchetti|first1=Francisco|title=Juntos crecieron, juntos jugaron, juntos viajaron, juntos paladearon la gloria; hoy, Raúl y Carlos Salinas encaran el naufragio|journal=Proceso|date=March 6, 1995|issue=957|page=21|language=Spanish}}</ref>) is a [[Mexicans|Mexican]] businessman who spent ten years in prison accused of the murder of his brother-in-law, [[José Francisco Ruiz Massieu]], but was acquitted in 2005.<ref name="swissinfo">{{cite news |url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/Salinas_funds_finally_head_back_to_Mexico.html?cid=6740256 |title=Salinas funds finally head back to Mexico |work=[[swissinfo]] |publisher=[[Swiss Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=18 June 2008 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> He is the brother of former [[President of Mexico]] [[Carlos Salinas]].
Salinas de Gortari was included in a list of the "10 most corrupt Mexicans" published by ''[[Forbes]]'' in 2013.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite web|title=The 10 Most Corrupt Mexicans Of 2013|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/doliaestevez/2013/12/16/the-10-most-corrupt-mexicans-of-2013/#2715e4857a0b798dfe167a8c|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref>
==Arrest and imprisonment== In February 1995, Raúl Salinas was arrested and charged with masterminding the murder of [[José Francisco Ruiz Massieu]], the deputy leader of the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party|PRI]] ruling party. Salinas was the former brother-in-law of Ruiz Massieu, who had been married to Raúl's sister Adriana.<ref>Salinas' Brother Charged in Mexican Assassination ''New York Times'' March 1, 1995 [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/01/world/salinas-s-brother-charged-in-mexican-assassination.html]</ref> In January 1999, Salinas was found guilty and sentenced to 50 years in prison (later reduced to 27.5 years).<ref>Raul Salinas Guilty in Killing And Is Sentenced to 50 Years ''New York Times'' January 22, 1999 [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/22/world/raul-salinas-guilty-in-killing-and-is-sentenced-to-50-years.html?ref=topics]</ref> In June 2005, Salinas had his conviction overturned by a judicial panel and he was released from prison.<ref>Mexico Voids Conviction of Ex-President's Brother ''Los Angeles Times'' June 10, 2005 [http://articles.latimes.com/2005/jun/10/world/fg-salinas10]</ref>
President Carlos Salinas appointed Deputy Attorney General [[:es:Mario Ruiz Massieu|Mario Ruiz Massieu]], the brother of the assassinated man, to head the investigation of the murder. However, after a few months he resigned, claiming senior PRI officials were blocking the investigation. Later, Ruiz Massieu fled the country, but was arrested in Newark, New Jersey on money-laundering charges. He died in September 1999, apparently by suicide.<ref> Mario Ruiz Massieu; As victim or perpetrator, he sank in a mire of murder, bribery and drug trafficking ''The Guardian'' September 1999 [https://www.theguardian.com/news/1999/sep/20/guardianobituaries1]</ref>
==Alleged money laundering==
In November 1995, Raúl Salinas's wife, [[Paulina Castañón]], and his brother-in-law, [[Antonio Castañón]], were arrested in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] after attempting to withdraw $84 million USD from an account owned by Raúl under an alias. Their capture led to the unveiling of a vast fortune spread around the world and summing to hundreds of millions of dollars even though he never officially received an annual income of more than $190,000. A report by the US [[General Accounting Office]] indicated that Raúl Salinas transferred over $90 million out of Mexico and into private bank accounts in London and Switzerland, through a complex set of transactions between 1992 and 1994, all with the help of [[Citibank]] and its affiliates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gao.gov/archive/1999/os99001.pdf |title=PRIVATE BANKING: Raul Salinas, Citibank, and Alleged Money Laundering |author=United States General Accounting Office |authorlink=Government Accountability Office |date=October 1998}}</ref>
In 2008, the government of Switzerland turned over $74 million out of the $110 million in frozen bank accounts held by Raúl Salinas, to the government of Mexico. The Swiss Justice Ministry indicated that the Mexican government had demonstrated that $66 million of the funds had been misappropriated, and the funds, with interest, were returned to Mexico. The bank accounts were held at [[Pictet & Cie]], Citibank Zurich, [[Julius Baer]] Bank, and [[Banque privée Edmond de Rothschild]] in Geneva and Zurich.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/mexico/news/reformaprison.html |title=He put his trust in Switzerland and Citibank |last=Rodriguez Reyna |first=Ignacio |work=[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]] |publisher=[[PBS]]}}</ref><ref name="Jordan1999">{{cite book|author=Jordan, David C.|title=Drug Politics: Dirty Money and Democracies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WK2HvMBKj4MC|year=1999|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-3174-0 |page=113}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.amleurope.org/materials/reference_Materials/Switzerlands%2012-Year%20Probe%20of%20Salinas%20Wnds%20with%20$74%20Million%20Payment%20to.pdf |title=Switzerland's 12-Year Probe of Salinas Ends with $74 Million Payment |publisher=[[Association of Certified Anti-Money Laundering Specialists]]}}{{dead link|date=February 2012}}</ref>
Other funds were returned to third parties, including Mexican billionaire [[Carlos Peralta Quintero]], who had given the funds to Raúl Salinas to set up an investment company. The Salinas family would not receive back any of the frozen funds.<ref name="swissinfo" /> However, in July 2013 a court exonerated Salinas of "unjust enrichment" and ordered that 224 million pesos (approximately $18 million) and 41 properties be returned to him. The court said that it could not explain how Salinas accumulated such wealth, but said that "so long as it is not shown that the assets acquired by public employee Raul Salinas de Gortari are proceeds derived from an abuse of his position," that he cannot be convicted of "unjust enrichment."<ref>Symbol of impunity: Raúl Salinas the "Inconvenient Relative" of President Carlos Salinas ''Borderline Beat'' August 5, 2013 [http://www.borderlandbeat.com/2013/08/symbol-of-impunity-raul-salinas.html]</ref>
On December 6, 2004, [[Enrique Salinas]] de Gortari, the brother of Raúl Salinas de Gortari, was found dead in his car after apparently having been beaten and strangled. Prosecutors said that Enrique Salinas had been sought for questioning by French police regarding his financial transactions with Raúl Salinas. However, investigators indicated that they thought the killing was a botched extortion attempt on him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Salinas Killing Deepens the Family's Drama |first=James C., Jr. |last=McKinley |authorlink=James C. McKinley, Jr. |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 10, 2004 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/10/international/americas/10mexico.html?_r=1&ref=raulsalinasdegortari}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Dellios |first=Hugh |title=Scent of a conspiracy bedevils Mexico murder |date=December 16, 2004 |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-12-16/news/0412160288_1_enrique-salinas-salinas-brother-raul-salinas-family}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
* Oppenheimer, Andres. ''Bordering on Chaos''. New York: Little, Brown, 1996. {{ISBN|0-316-65095-1}}.
==External links== *{{cite news |title=Murder, Money and Mexico | |url= https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/mexico/family/raulsalinas.html|work=[[PBS Frontline]]}} *{{cite news |title=Raul Salinas accused of $100m drugs laundering |date=October 20, 1998 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/197773.stm |work=[[BBC News]]}} *{{cite news |last=Bruce |first=Ian |title=Mexico frees ex-leader's brother |date=June 10, 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4079372.stm |work=[[BBC News]]}}
{{Mexican Drug War}}

revision.comment: /* Management */ Add [[:Category:Television channel articles with incorrect naming style]]
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=September 2007}} :''For the similarly named television station that formerly aired in Canada, see [[The Score Television Network]].''
'''SCORE''' was the weekend sports service of the [[Financial News Network]] which aired sports-themed programming starting in 1985. It was renamed FNN Sports in 1990 when FNN decided to go with a 24-hour feed on weekdays. SCORE was forced to dissolve after [[CNBC]] bought out FNN in 1991.
SCORE used a sports ticker or crawl to update scores at the bottom of the screen. As it was a co-venture with FNN, a stock ticker was often shown across the bottom of the screen. SCORE provided scores and highlight updates every half-hour.
==Programming== SCORE had several shows that were televised versions of what [[sports talk]] radio is today. SCORE featured some professional sporting events, live call-in shows, and sports news shows. Live sporting events included [[professional wrestling]], [[Major Soccer League|MISL]] [[soccer]], [[college basketball]], the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]] and [[boxing]]. It also broadcast a couple [[NASCAR]] races in [[1988 in NASCAR|1988]] that were originally slated for [[Special Events Television Network|SETN]] before it folded.
It also showed at least two games of the 1986 [[National Invitation Tournament]].
===Call-in shows, including Time Out for Trivia=== Its most popular show was ''Time Out for Trivia'', hosted by [[Todd Donoho]] and produced by Eric Corwin. ''Time Out For Trivia'' was the first national live interactive game show in which viewers phoned in and if they correctly answered a question, they'd win a prize. One of the most popular prizes on the show was the [[Dirt Devil]] [[vacuum cleaner]] which often included a funny sound effect like an "ooooh" or an "oooooh.... aaaaaah." Humor was almost always an ingredient, particularly in the multiple-choice questions, which often included an obvious nonsports figure as one of the possible answers.
''Time Out For Trivia'' became a cult hit on cable TV, receiving many glowing reviews in newspapers and magazines. Gary Nuhn, a columnist for the ''[[Dayton Daily News]]'', has called TOFT "cable TV at its best," and Wendell Barnhouse, radio/TV columnist for the ''[[Star-Telegram|Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]'', says it is "one of life's joys." ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' did a feature about ''TOFT'' in its famous swimsuit issue.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1067034/index.htm] Donoho and Corwin did over 1,000 shows together, including a 1,000th show "special edition", a one-hour program which featured highlights from the first 999 shows. Donoho and Corwin worked together on ''TOFT'' and other shows at FNN/SCORE from 1985 through 1989 before joining the sports department at [[KABC-TV|KABC]]. Much of this show was incorporated into a show on KABC called ''Monday Night Live'', which aired after ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' from {{nfly|1990}} to {{nfly|1999}}, when Donoho's contract was not renewed by KABC. The show was then renamed ''Sports Zone'' with host Rob Fukuzaki and it remained an ''MNF'' postgame show until the package left ABC after the 2005 season. ''Sports Zone'' remains on KABC, following many events televised by the network.
Other call-in shows included ''The Fan Speaks Out'', ''The Final Score'', and ''The Sports Collector''.
===News programs=== News shows featured included ''Tennis Talk'', a baseball program called ''The Hot Stove League'', and a sports wagering program with [[Wayne Root]]. Other hosts included [[Bill Brown (broadcaster)|Bill Brown]], [[Byron Day]], John Loesing, Hugh Malay and Fred Wallin. Many of the shows were directed by Brad Toberman. Show producers included Jim Battey, Michael Pierce, Steven Herbert, Gary Kubik, Hugh Malay, Eric Corwin and Steven Friedman.
===Professional wrestling=== The professional wrestling programming exposed fans throughout the country to regional territory wrestling promotions. These territories included the [[Jim Crockett Promotions|Mid-Atlantic]] with [[Ric Flair]] and Chief [[Wahoo McDaniel]], [[Continental Wrestling Federation|Memphis]] with [[Jerry Lawler|Jerry 'the King' Lawler]], [[World Class Championship Wrestling|Texas]] with the Von Erichs and the Maivia family's [[Hawaii]] promotion with [[Rocky Johnson]], [[King Curtis]], [[Don Muraco]], [[Lawrence Heinemi|Lars Anderson]], [[Superfly Snuka]], [[Bruiser Brody]] and many [[Japan]]ese wrestlers. It also prominently featured wrestling from the [[Continental Championship Wrestling|Continental Wrestling Federation]] including matches featuring [[Eddie Gilbert (wrestler)|Eddie Gilbert]], [[Tom Prichard]], and [[Tony Anthony (wrestler) | The Dirty White Boy]].
== Management == *President: Arnie Rosenthal
{{U.S. premium television services}} {{NASCAR on television and radio}}

{{about||the Australian television series|Shark Tank (Australian TV series)|the arena in San Jose, California|SAP Center at San Jose}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Shark Tank | image = [[File:Shark Tank Logo.jpg|250px]] | genre = [[Reality television]] | creator = [[Mark Burnett]] | based_on = ''[[Dragons' Den]]'' | director = {{unbulleted list|Craig Spirko|Ken Fuchs|[[Alan Carter (director)|Alan Carter]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Kevin O'Leary]] * [[Barbara Corcoran]] * [[Daymond John]] * [[Robert Herjavec]] * [[Lori Greiner]] * [[Mark Cuban]] * [[Kevin Harrington (entrepreneur)|Kevin Harrington]] }} | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 10 | num_episodes = 206 | list_episodes = List of Shark Tank episodes | executive_producer = {{unbulleted list|Clay Newbill|[[Mark Burnett]]|Yun Lingner|Phil Gurin}} | camera = [[Multiple-camera setup|Multiple-camera]] | runtime = 42 minutes | company = {{unbulleted list|Mark Burnett Productions
(2009–11)
One Three Media
(2012–14)
[[United Artists|United Artists Media Group]]
(2014–15)
[[MGM Television]]
(2016–)
[[Sony Pictures Television]]}} | distributor = Sony Pictures Television | channel = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] | picture_format = [[720p]] ([[16:9]] [[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | audio_format = [[Stereophonic sound|Stereo]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2009|8|9}} | last_aired = present | website = http://abc.go.com/shows/shark-tank | related = ''[[Beyond the Tank]]'' }} '''''Shark Tank''''' is an American [[Reality television#Investments|reality television series]] that premiered on August 9, 2009, on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]].Hibberd, James (May 10, 2012)[http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/05/10/abc-dancing-with-the-stars-shark-tank/ 'Dancing,' 'Bachelor,' and a bigger 'Shark Tank' returning to ABC] Insider TV. Retrieved June 24, 2012 The show is a franchise of the international format ''[[Dragons' Den]]'', which originated in Japan in 2001.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/shark-tank-international-versions-2013-11|title=Here's What 'Shark Tank' Looks Like In 9 Different Countries|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-11-26}} ''Shark Tank'' shows aspiring [[entrepreneurship|entrepreneurs]] as they make business presentations to a panel of five "shark" [[investor]]s, who then choose whether to invest as business partners. The series has been a [[Nielsen ratings|ratings]] success in its time slot and has won the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Structured Reality Program]] four times, from 2014 through 2017, in all four years of that category's existence. Prior to that, from 2012 to 2013, it won [[Outstanding Reality Program]]. ''Shark Tank'''s tenth season premiered on October 7, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://patch.com/nevada/lasvegas/abc-show-shark-tank-casting-las-vegas-thursday/|title='Shark Tank renewed for Season 10, Casting begins in Las Vegas|date=January 12, 2018|accessdate=January 12, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/roseanne-the-connors-1202882075/|title=ABC Fall Premiere Dates: ‘Roseanne’ Spinoff ‘The Conners’ Sets Debut|last=Holloway|first=Daniel|date=July 24, 2018|access-date=July 24, 2018|website=Variety}} ==Overview== ''Shark Tank'' is produced by [[Mark Burnett]] and based on the format ''[[Dragons' Den]]'', which originated in 2001 with the Japanese show ''Tigers of Money''.Adalian, Josef (February 13, 2008). [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117980906.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 "Sony, Burnett dive into 'Shark Tank'"]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', "a version of the Japanese reality format." ''Shark Tank,'' however, more closely resembles the format of the [[Dragons' Den (UK TV series)|British version]] of ''Dragons' Den'', which premiered in 2005.{{cite web|last=Dehnart|first=Andy|title='Shark Tank's’ Sneak Attack!|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/05/11/shark-tank-s-sneak-attack.html|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=October 11, 2013|date=May 11, 2012|quote="Based on ''Dragon's Den'', the U.K. version of a Japanese format, Shark Tank gives people..."}}Wilson, W. Brett (2012). ''Redefining Success: Still Making Mistakes'', Penguin Books, page 122, {{ISBN|9780670066940}}{{quotation needed|date=October 2013}}Battaglio, Stephen (December 3, 2012) "''Shark'' Attacks Prime Time!". ''[[TV Guide]]''. pp. 4–5{{quotation needed|date=October 2013}}O'Leary, Kevin (2012). ''Cold Hard Truth on Business, Money & Life'', Random House, page 8, {{ISBN|9780385671767}}{{quotation needed|date=October 2013}} The show features a panel of potential investors, called "sharks," who consider offers from aspiring entrepreneurs seeking investments for their business or product.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jan/10/entertainment/la-et-st-winter-tca-shark-tank-corporate-ladder-20130110 | title=Winter TCA: 'Shark Tank' star calls corporate ladder 'all crap' | newspaper=Los Angeles Times| date=January 10, 2013 | accessdate=March 21, 2013 | author=Collins, Scott}} The sharks are paid for their participation in the show, but the money they invest is their own.{{cite news| url=http://communityvoices.post-gazette.com/arts-entertainment-living/tuned-in/item/38746-tv-q-a-shark-tank-longmire-and-wepa | title=TV Q&A: 'Shark Tank,' 'Longmire' and WEPA | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette| date=January 23, 2015 | accessdate=January 23, 2015 | author=Owen, Rob}} The entrepreneur can make a deal on the show if a panel member is interested. However, if all of the panel members opt out, the entrepreneur leaves empty-handed. The show is said to portray "the drama of pitch meetings and the interaction between the entrepreneurs and tycoons."{{cite web | url=http://au.businessinsider.com/abc-to-humiliate-struggling-entrepreneurs-on-national-television-2009-3 | title=ABC To Humiliate Entrepreneurs on National TV | publisher=Business Insider (Australia) | date=March 31, 2009 | accessdate=March 21, 2013 | author=Lewis, Hilary | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130410162807/http://au.businessinsider.com/abc-to-humiliate-struggling-entrepreneurs-on-national-television-2009-3 | archivedate=April 10, 2013 | df=mdy-all }} A one-hour pitch by a contestant is edited down to "a dramatic 10-minute segment."{{cite web | url=http://au.businessinsider.com/23-year-old-turns-down-big-money-from-mark-cuban-2012-9 | title=23-Year-Old Turns Down Big Money From Mark Cuban | publisher=Business Insider (Australia) | date=September 22, 2012 | accessdate=March 21, 2013 | author=Shontell, Allyson | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926144858/http://www.businessinsider.com.au/23-year-old-turns-down-big-money-from-mark-Cuban-2012-9 | archivedate=September 26, 2013 | df=mdy-all }} Two of the show's longstanding "sharks," [[Robert Herjavec]] and [[Kevin O'Leary]], are Canadian entrepreneurs who had previously appeared on the [[Dragons' Den (Canadian TV series)|Canadian version]] of ''Dragons' Den''. The "sharks" often find weaknesses and faults in an entrepreneur's concept, product, or business model. Some of the investors try to soften the impact of rejection, like panel member Corcoran, while others such as O'Leary can be "brutal" and show "no patience even for tales of hardship". Many, and possibly a majority, of the deals made on the show are never enacted, due to the investors' [[vetting]] process following the deal, which includes product testing and the examination of the contestants' personal and business financials.{{cite web | url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/tv/deal_interrupted_cPMIlS95ZcxoPT9UUxVLPP | title=Deal interrupted: On ‘Shark Tank,’ a lot can happen after the handshake | work=New York Post | date=January 29, 2013 | accessdate=March 21, 2013 | author=Daly, Shawn}} In some cases, the entrepreneurs themselves have backed out of the deal after admitting that they only wanted to appear on the show for the publicity.{{cite web |title=Shark Tank Roundtable – Their Best and Worst Deals |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danschawbel/2012/06/04/shark-tank-roundtable-their-best-and-worst-deals/ |first=Dan |last=Schawbel |work=Forbes |date=June 4, 2012 |quote=When we started dealing with these ["Hill Billy"] guys they said "we just wanted to be on TV for the free advertisement, we didn't really want to do a deal with you."}} The show is often responsible for what has become known as the ''Shark Tank'' effect.{{cite web|url=https://www.americanexpress.com/us/small-business/openforum/articles/the-shark-tank-effect-how-even-the-shows-losers-became-winners|title=THE "SHARK TANK" EFFECT: HOW EVEN THE SHOW'S LOSERS BECAME WINNERS|author=Vivian Giang|accessdate=26 July 2018}} Simply appearing on the show, even without getting an offer, has the potential to significantly boost sales for companies.{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/201505/john-brandon/the-shark-tank-effect.html|title=Here's What Happened Next to Shark Tank's 10 Biggest Winners|author=John Brandon|accessdate=26 July 2018}} Some entrepreneurs have reported revenue increases of 10-20 times after the show's airing.{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/278201|title=The Shark Tank Effect: This Entrepreneur 'Felt' the Power of the Show|author=Andrew Medal|accessdate=28 July 2018}} The show initially required each contestant to sign an agreement with Finnmax, the producer of ''Shark Tank'', promising Finnmax the option of taking a "2 percent royalty" or "5% equity stake" in the contestant's business venture.{{cite web | url=http://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/19/passing-up-the-opportunity-to-appear-on-shark-tank/ | title=Passing Up the Opportunity to Appear on 'Shark Tank' | work=The New York Times | date=September 19, 2012 | accessdate=March 21, 2013 | author=Kassar, Ami}} However, in October 2013, this requirement was repealed by the network, retroactively, due to pressure from panel member [[Mark Cuban]].{{cite web | url=http://www.inc.com/will-yakowicz/mark-cuban-forces-shark-tank-to-remove-equity-clause.html | title=Mark Cuban Made Shark Tank Change Its Contracts | publisher=Inc. magazine | date=October 2, 2013 | accessdate=October 10, 2013 | author=Yankowicz, Will}} Cuban felt the requirement would lower the quality of the entrepreneurs, as savvy investors would be wary of trading away a portion of their company just for appearing on the show. A number of potential entrepreneurs have declined to participate in the show for this reason.{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/john-mcdermott/shark-tank-not-for-every-entrepreneur.html|title=Shark Tank: Not for Every Entrepreneur|publisher=Inc.com|accessdate=August 12, 2015}} ==Episodes== {{main|List of Shark Tank episodes}} {{:List of Shark Tank episodes}} ''Shark Tank'' premiered in August 2009 and aired 14 episodes through January 2010. In August, it was renewed for a second season. Season 2 premiered with a "sneak peek" episode on Sunday, March 20, 2011, before resuming its regular Friday night time slot on March 25, 2011. Season 2 had 9 episodes, 5 of them featuring new panel members. Comedian [[Jeff Foxworthy]]DiNunno, Gina (August 10, 2010). [http://www.tvguide.com/News/Shark-Tank-Foxworthy-1021700.aspx?rss=news&partnerid=spi&profileid=05 "Jeff Foxworthy Joins ABC's ''Shark Tank''"]. ''[[TV Guide]]''. and Mark Cuban replaced panel member [[Kevin Harrington (entrepreneur)|Kevin Harrington]] in those episodes.[http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/shark-tank-mark-cuban-season-two-18335/ "Shark Tank: Mark Cuban Joins the Sharks for Season Two"]. TV Series Finale. September 20, 2010 In season 2, Kevin O'Leary, Barbara Corcoran, Daymond John, and Robert Herjavec appeared in all nine episodes; Harrington appeared in four, Cuban in three, and Foxworthy in two.{{cite web|last=Schawbel|first=Dan|title=Shark Tank Roundtable – Their Best and Worst Deals|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danschawbel/2012/06/04/shark-tank-roundtable-their-best-and-worst-deals/|accessdate=October 21, 2013}} ''Shark Tank'''s third season premiered in January 2012.{{cite web|last=Bentley|first=Jean|title=TV Ratings: CBS repeats win Friday over 'Shark Tank' debut|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2012/01/tv-ratings-cbs-repeats-win-over-shark-tank-debut.html|accessdate=January 21, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120123000053/http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2012/01/tv-ratings-cbs-repeats-win-over-shark-tank-debut.html|archivedate=January 23, 2012|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|last=Stein|first=Rachel|title=Going Through Channels: Friday, January 20, 2012: Shark Tank|url=http://www.televisionwithoutpity.com/goingthroughchannels/2012/01/friday-january-20-2012-shark-tank.php|accessdate=January 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124011605/http://www.televisionwithoutpity.com/goingthroughchannels/2012/01/friday-january-20-2012-shark-tank.php|archivedate=January 24, 2012|df=mdy-all}} During the second season, Kevin Harrington was replaced by [[Mark Cuban]], while in the third season, the "queen of QVC" [[Lori Greiner]] replaced Barbara Corcoran on 4 episodes. [[Kevin O'Leary]], [[Daymond John]], [[Robert Herjavec]], and [[Mark Cuban]] appeared in all 15 episodes of season three. In February, ABC ordered two additional episodes for season 3 using unaired footage, which brought the season's episode total to 15.{{cite web|last=Hibberd|first=James|title=ABC orders more 'Shark Tank'|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/02/27/abc-shark-tank/}} On May 10, 2012, Shark Tank was renewed for a fourth season consisting of 26 episodes.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/10/22/abcs-shark-tank-recieves-order-for-two-additional-episodes-for-2012-2013-season/154247/|title=ABC's 'Shark Tank' Receives Order for Two Additional Episodes for 2012–2013 Season – Ratings | TVbytheNumbers|publisher=tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com|accessdate=April 24, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113084632/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/10/22/abcs-shark-tank-recieves-order-for-two-additional-episodes-for-2012-2013-season/154247/|archivedate=November 13, 2014|df=mdy-all}} This is the first time the series received a full season order.{{cite web|last=Jensen|first=Jeff|title='DWTS,' 'Bachelor,' and a bigger 'Shark Tank' return |url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/05/10/abc-dancing-with-the-stars-shark-tank/}} Filming began on June 30, 2012. According to [[TV Guide]], as of December 2012, the show's panel members had invested $12.4 million in the business opportunities presented to them during that season. Those whose business ideas did not result in an investment from the sharks still benefited from the publicity generated by that contestant appearing on the show. During the show's 2012 season, 36,076 people applied to become contestants. In 2013, ABC renewed the show for a fifth season.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/05/14/abc-2013-14-primetime-schedule-marvels-agents-of-s-h-i-e-l-d-on-tuesday-revenge-sticks-with-sunday-once-upon-a-time-spinoff-on-thursday/182567/|title=ABC 2013–14 Primetime Schedule: ‘Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.’ on Tuesday, ‘Revenge’ Sticks With Sunday, ‘Once Upon a Time’ Spinoff on Thursday, ‘DWTS’ Downsized & More – Ratings | TVbytheNumbers|publisher=tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com|accessdate=April 24, 2014}} Season 5 premiered on September 20, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/07/16/abc-sets-premiere-dates-for-2013-2014-season-including-s-h-i-e-l-d-once-upon-a-time-in-wonderland-modern-family-scandal-more/192284/|title=ABC Sets Premiere Dates for 2013–2014 Season Including 'Marvel's Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.', 'Once Upon a Time in Wonderland' & More – Ratings | TVbytheNumbers|publisher=tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com|accessdate=April 24, 2014}} In October 2013, ABC ordered an additional two episodes for the season. In December 2013, ABC ordered another four episodes, bringing the season order to 29 episodes.{{cite news| url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/abc-orders-more-shark-tank-647238 | work=The Hollywood Reporter | first=Kimberly | last=Nordyke | title=ABC Orders More 'Shark Tank' (Exclusive) | date=October 10, 2013}}{{cite news| url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/abc-orders-four-more-episodes-665098 | work=The Hollywood Reporter | first=Kimberly | last=Nordyke | title=ABC Orders Four More Episodes of 'Shark Tank' (Exclusive) | date=December 12, 2013}} [[Steve Tisch]] and [[John Paul DeJoria]] were added as panel members.{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/new-york-giants-chairman-steve-tisch-joining-abc-shark-tank-article-1.1385111 | title=New York Giants co-owner Steve Tisch joining ABC's 'Shark Tank' | date=June 28, 2013|newspaper=Daily News| accessdate=July 3, 2013 | author=Hinckley, David }}{{cite web | url=http://www.tvmediainsights.com/highlights/26349/friday-june-28-2013/ | title=Two More Sharks on ABC | publisher=TV Media Insights | date=June 28, 2013 | accessdate=July 1, 2013 }} In 2013, [[CNBC]] licensed exclusive off-network cable rights for the series from ABC.[https://www.cnbc.com/id/101078157 "CNBC Licenses Off-Network Cable Rights to 'Shark Tank' from Disney-ABC Television Group"]. [[CNBC]]. October 1, 2013 In May 2014, ABC announced a sixth season starting in September 2014.{{cite web | url=http://www.zap2it.com/tv/shark-tank/SH011581290000 | title='The Bachelor', 'Shark Tank' and 'America's Funniest Home Videos' all renewed by ABC | publisher=zap2it | date=May 9, 2014 | accessdate=May 30, 2014 | author= Sarah Huggins }} The series began its syndication run on [[CNBC]] on December 30, 2013.Pucci, Douglas (January 6, 2014). [http://tvmediainsights.com/highlights/37684/shark-tank-scores-for-cnbc-on-new-years-day "''Shark Tank'' Scores for CNBC on New Year's Day"]. The seventh season of the show premiered on Friday, September 25, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://when-will.net/tv-series/826-will-there-be-shark-tank-season-7-release-date.html|title=Shark Tank season 7 premiere date – September 25, 2015|accessdate=August 12, 2015}} Actor/investor [[Ashton Kutcher]], music manager/CEO [[Troy Carter (music industry)|Troy Carter]], and venture investor [[Chris Sacca]] all appeared as guest sharks.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexkonrad/2015/07/20/kutcher-sacca-and-carter-join-shark-tank/|title=Ashton Kutcher, Troy Carter And Chris Sacca Test Investing Chops on New Season Of 'Shark Tank'|author=Alex Konrad|date=July 20, 2015|work=Forbes|accessdate=August 12, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://aplus.com/a/ashton-kutcher-shark-tank-investment-strategy/|title=Ashton Kutcher Set To Appear On 'Shark Tank' Reveals Investment Strategy'|author=Isaac Saul|date=Sep 2, 2015|work=A Plus|accessdate=October 8, 2015}}{{Cite news|url=https://startupmindset.com/shark-tank-net-worth-1/|title=Here Are the Net Worths of the Investors on Shark Tank - StartUp Mindset|date=2018-08-01|work=StartUp Mindset|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US}} The ninth season of the show premiered on Sunday, October 1, 2017,https://www.realityblurred.com/realitytv/2017/10/shark-tank-season-9-new-set-changes/ with a new, modern looking set, new chairs, more space, and guest shark Richard
